general.para: Personnel disassembling the engine or modules should read the Introduction Sections of this manual to familiarize themselves with the general overhaul procedures (Ref. INTRODUCTION, How to Use this Manual).

Disassembly is divided into three sections: DISASSEMBLY-1 through DISASSEMBLY-3. Unscheduled removal of the power section from gas generator assembly is found in DISASSEMBLY-3.
ENGINE DISASSEMBLY-1: EXTERNAL COMPONENTS
ENGINE DISASSEMBLY-2: ACCESSORY COMPONENTS
ENGINE DISASSEMBLY-3: MAJOR SUBASSEMBLIES

On receipt of an engine for overhaul, remove air inlet screen and examine for foreign object damage (FOD) in compressor rotor assembly. Inspect for external damage, burning, corrosion, and signs of leakage. Record all observations made at this inspection to provide reference during disassembly of engine; special notice is to be made of any discrepancy which might not be apparent after cleaning. All affected parts must be tagged to identify nature of fault and, after removal from engine, be subjected to detailed inspection before cleaning.

During inspection of engine, check that all externally mounted parts and accessories are correctly fitted; loose and/or unattached components usually indicates these parts have been replaced due to a previous unserviceability. Record all discrepancies and check against data sheets received with engine for information relating to unserviceabilities encountered during service.

Overhaul facilities may find it more expedient to remove certain parts before others, so disassembly sequences given in the text need not be strictly adhered to. Instructions for removal of some standard parts, such as loop clamps and similar attaching hardware, may be repeated in areas where such parts support more than one component.

Seal all openings as soon as possible after removal of external parts and accessory units. Place each component in a separate polyethylene bag or dust-proof container, and store on suitable racks until required for overhaul. Segregate the parts during storage to prevent impact damage.
When an engine is separated at the bolting flanges, install major assemblies in appropriate stands, cover with plastic sheeting and seal to prevent ingress of moisture and foreign material.

To prevent damaging seal grooves and lands, use plastic spatulas for removing preformed packings. Damage in these areas can cause leaks due to improper seating. Discard all preformed packings, packing retainers, backup rings, tabwashers, cotterpins and gaskets immediately after removal to prevent possible reuse of these parts.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Remove Center Fireseal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove self-locking nuts (7) pt6a38-723001-001-0100 4 and bolts (6) pt6a38-723001-001-0080 4 securing top center fireseal mounting ring (1) to bottom center fireseal mounting ring (5) at each side of engine.

Support bottom center fireseal mounting ring (5), remove self-locking nuts (18) pt6a38-723001-001-0100 1 and bolts (17) pt6a38-723001-001-0080 1 securing ring to fireseal support brackets (2) located on gas generator case, and lower mounting ring from engine.

Remove self-locking nuts (20) pt6a38-723001-001-0100 1 , washers (19) pt6a38-723001-001-0090 2 and
bolts (8) pt6a38-723001-001-0080 1 securing top center fireseal mounting ring (1) to fireseal support brackets (2) located on gas generator case, and lift mounting ring from engine.
Do an overhaul of the removed parts (Ref. 72-30-01).

procedure.title: Remove Rear Fireseal (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove self-locking nuts (12) pt6a38-742000-001-0040 2 and bolts (16) pt6a38-742000-001-0020 4 to release fireseal support bracket (10) and ignition cables (15) from bottom rear fireseal mounting ring (4). Removal of bolt (13) and scavenge oil tube (11), and removal of ignition cables (15), is dealt with in preceding paragraphs.

Support bottom rear fireseal mounting ring (4), remove self-locking nuts (14) pt6a38-723002-001-0100 2 and
bolts (9) pt6a38-723002-001-0090 2 securing top rear fireseal mounting ring (3) to bottom mounting ring (4), and remove both rings. On 3258 engines, remove spacers (21) pt6a38-723002-001-0095 4 from between top and bottom mounting rings.
Overhaul removed parts (Ref. 72-30-02).

procedure.title: Remove Power Section from Engine (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Place suitable oil container under propeller reduction gearbox (7), remove chip detector (8) pt6a38-721000-007-0010 1 , and allow residual oil to drain from gearbox.
Install power section sling (PWC32073) or (PWC34073) on propeller reduction gearbox (7).
Position mounting plate of sling (1) (PWC32073) or (PWC34073) over propeller mounting flange on reduction gearbox (7) and engage dowels on flange with corresponding holes in plate.
Secure sling (1) to propeller mounting flange with four socket-head cap screws (17), installed from rear of mounting flange. Tighten screws, and torque 700 to 770 lb.in.
Attach hoist to lifting lug on sling (1), and take up slack on hoist to support weight of power section.
Remove self-locking nuts (2) pt6a38-723004-001-0220 55 and bolts (4) pt6a38-723004-001-0210 55 securing exhaust duct (3) to gas generator case (5) at flange C.
Using the hoist and sling, separate power section and withdraw from gas generator case.
3337 and PT6A-42A: remove and discard collapsed seal ring (18) pt6a38-725005-001-0060 1 .

Install mount ring (PWC30269) and two engine stand adapters (PWC32052) or (PWC34752) on power section as follows: Place mount ring (9) on flange of exhaust duct (3), position with set of three holes at each side of horizontal plane, and attach with bolts (11) and self-locking nuts (12). Attach one adapter (10) to each set of three holes in mount ring (9) with hexagon head machine screws (13).
Lower power section into stand (PWC34300) or (PWC51140) or (PWC70907) and attach adapters (10) to mounting disks on stand with bolts (14), washers (15) and nuts (16). Tighten nuts securely.
Remove sling (1) from power section.
Overhaul chip detector (Ref. 72-10-00).
Overhaul power section (Ref. 72-01-00).

procedure.title: Remove Accessory Gearbox From the Gas Generator Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove oil drain plug (10) pt6a38-726000-001-0420 1 and allow residual oil to drain from accessory gearbox. Reinstall oil drain plug to prevent loss of part.

Using accessory gearbox transfer tube puller (PWC30128-04), withdraw oil transfer tube (18) pt6a38-722000-002-0180 1 from elbow boss inside accessory gearbox, and remove tube from bottom of compressor inlet case (19). Remove and discard
preformed packings (17) pt6a38-722000-002-0190 2 .

Remove parts from center boss in rear face of accessory gearbox as follows : For 3274 Engines: Remove plug (6) pt6a38-726000-001-0320 1 . Remove and discard preformed packing (5) pt6a38-726000-001-0330 1 . For 3274 Engines: Remove oil jet nozzle (25) pt6a38-726000-001-0325 1 . Remove and discard preformed packings (5) pt6a38-726000-001-0330 1 and (26) pt6a38-726000-001-0335 1 . For 3317 Engines: Remove oil jet nozzle assembly (27) pt6a38-726000-001-0460 1 . Remove and discard preformed packings
(5) pt6a38-726000-001-0330 1 and (26) pt6a38-726000-001-0335 1 .
For 3277/PT6A-42A Engines: Look through hole of center boss and rotate compressor until notch in washer is at 3 o'clock position, indicating lock ball (16) is at 12 o'clock position.

For 3277 Engines: Insert fixture (PWC34060) through gearbox, coupling shaft, and engage tangs of fixture in slots of lock insert; insert puller (PWC34062) through coupling shaft, and screw into spring lock insert within rear hub coupling (12). Remove insert.

Put accessory gearbox drive-shaft puller/pusher (PWC30373) through center boss in rear face of accessory gearbox and into centerebore of coupling shaft (1). Tighten nut on puller/pusher to remove end-float on coupling shaft with your hands.

Remove three self-locking nuts (4) pt6a38-726000-001-0010 3 securing engine lifting bracket (3) and accessory gearbox to upper studs on compressor inlet case (19). Remove bracket pt6a38-726000-001-0030 1 .

THE ACCESSORY GEARBOX DIAPHRAGM (21) AND HOUSING (11) ARE SECURED TOGETHER BY FOUR COUNTERSUNK SCREWS AND SELF-LOCKING NUTS. ASSUMING THE 12 O'CLOCK POSITION TO BE NO. 1, NUTS AND SCREWS SECURING DIAPHRAGM TO HOUSING ARE LOCATED AT POSITIONS NO. 4, 8, 14 and 18 VIEWED CLOCKWISE. THESE FOUR NUTS MUST NOT BE REMOVED.Remove remaining self-locking nuts (4) pt6a38-726000-001-0010 11 , securing accessory gearbox to studs on compressor inlet case (19) and remove three spacers (22) pt6a38-726000-001-0020 3 and washers (20 pt6a38-726000-001-0020 3 ).

Install accessory gearbox case jackscrews (PWC32396) in four flange jacking inserts, located at each of the diaphragm to housing attachment nuts, and carefully separate accessory gearbox from studs on compressor inlet case (19) by tightening on alternate jackscrews.
Replace puller/pusher (PWC30373) with holder (PWC32076) in coupling shaft to prevent it becoming disengaged and causing possible damage. Remove accessory gearbox from compressor inlet case.

For 3277/PT6A-42A Engines: Remove and discard lockball (16). If lockball (16, 3277/PT6A-42A) drops out of locking arrangement between compressor hub coupling (12) and coupling shaft (1) during removal of accessory gearbox, retrieve ball from No. 1 bearing housing area or from oil scavenge passage in compressor inlet case (19), as applicable and discard.
If oil tank center tube (14) and two oil transfer tubes are withdrawn with accessory gearbox, remove tubes from gearbox and reinstall in compressor inlet case (19).
Install accessory gearbox in accessory gearbox stand (PWC30517).
Enclose 3274 plug (6) or 3274 oil jet nozzle (25), as applicable in a protective bag and retain with accessory gearbox.
Overhaul accessory gearbox (Ref. 72-60-00).
Overhaul generator assembly (Ref. 72-30-00).

n-para.title: Removal of Power Section from Gas Generator Assembly for Unscheduled Overhaul

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: Install engine in stand (PWC34300) or (PWC51140) or (PWC70907) (Ref. Storage Instructions).

Install power output section sling (PWC34300) or (PWC51140) or (PWC70907) on RGB (Ref. Para. ) (Ref. Fig. ): Place suitable container under reduction gearbox (15), and remove chip detector (14) pt6a38-721000-007-0010 1 from boss at 6 o'clock position. Allow oil to drain. Disconnect
coupling nut (5) pt6a38-731008-001-0120 pt6a38-731008-002-0130 1 of governor pneumatic (Py) line at bulkhead fitting (9) at center fireseal (10). Cap lines. Disconnect engine accessories mounted on reduction gearbox as necessary. Remove cotterpin pt6a38-761000-003-0180 1 , nut pt6a38-761000-003-0170 1 , bolt pt6a38-761000-003-0160 and spacer securing clevis end of push-pull terminal (3) to propeller reversing lever (17). Remove cotterpin, nut, washers, spacer and bolt securing propeller governor interconnecting rod (4) to airbleed link on propeller governor (1). Release
locknut (7) pt6a38-761000-002-0090 1 securing front swivel joint (6) of propeller reversing linkage to front lifting bracket. Remove inner nut pt6a38-761000-003-0030 1 and bolt pt6a38-761000-003-0020 1 , and release outer nut pt6a38-761000-003-0030 1 and bolt pt6a38-761000-003-0020 1 securing swivel joint retaining plate to front lifting bracket. Disconnect loop clamp supporting Py pneumatic tube by removing nut and bolt from swivel joint retaining plate (3049). Swing retaining plate and lift forward end of propeller reversing linkage clear of front lifting bracket. Suitably support linkage. Remove bolts pt6a38-772001-003-0100 pt6a38-772001-003-0110 1, 1 (3114) or nuts pt6a38-772001-003-0105 pt6a38-772001-003-0115 1, 1 (3114) securing T5 thermocouple wiring harness to T5 thermocouple terminal on gas generator case. Remove wiring harness lugs. Temporarily secure T5 trim harness and airframe leads, if applicable, to terminal with bolts. Tighten bolts fingertight only. Attach hoist to lifting lug on sling (2), and take up slack on hoist to support weight of power section.
DO NOT ROTATE OR DISTURB INTERSTAGE SEALING RINGS ON COMPRESSOR TURBINE STATOR HOUSING UNLESS THEY ARE REMOVED FOR INSPECTION.Remove nuts and bolts at flange C (8), and separate power output section from gas generator case. Using sling, partially withdraw power output section. Cap all tubes (12), and install plugs on couplings (13). Withdraw power section from gas generator case and install in stand (Ref. Para. ). 3337 and PT6A-42A: remove and discard collapsed seal ring (18) pt6a38-725005-001-0060 1 .

figure.title: Removal of Power Section from Gas-generator Case for Unscheduled Overhaul

title.xref: Removal of Power Section from Gas-generator Case for Unscheduled Overhaul

general.para: Personnel employed on overhaul of the engine should acquaint themselves with the INTRODUCTION sections of this manual.

General cleaning procedures in this chapter and specific cleaning procedures in each of the other chapters should be used in conjunction with cleaning procedures described in P&WA Standard Practices Manual P/N 585005.

Certain cleaning procedures used in the manual will refer to the letter prefix SPOP, an abbreviation for Service Process Operation Procedure, followed by a control number, e.g., SPOP 209, VAPOR DEGREASING. Whenever any normal SPOP cleaning method is specified, reference should be made to P&WA Standard Practices Manual for detailed information.

Where a chapter/section/unit provides specific cleaning procedures for engine parts or assemblies, an illustration is provided. To avoid repetitive cleaning information on similar parts such as bearings, tubes etc., reference will be made to this chapter/section/unit.

All engine parts, other than standard replacement parts such as gaskets and preformed packings, should be cleaned in accordance with SPOP 209. Tubes in this category must be blown through with clean, dry compressed air and examined to ensure they are unobstructed. Cap all tubes immediately after cleaning to prevent the entry of contaminants which could affect engine operation.
If cleaning of tubes specified in applicable chapter is ineffective, additional cleaning should be carried out as described in para
Segregate bearings from other engine parts and handle carefully (Ref. 70-20, P&WA Standard Practices Manual). Clean bearings as specified in table of applicable chapter/section.
Permanent type oil filter element is cleaned ultrasonically. Disposable type element is cleaned electrosonically and must not be cleaned ultrasonically (Ref. Chapter 79-20-04).

In addition to the above SPOP's, Service Process Operation Procedure numbers prefixed with a letter "U" are of P&WC origin, e.g. SPOP U002, PERMANENT-TYPE OIL FILTER CLEANING AND INSPECTION. These SPOP's are described in this chapter, to which reference will be made from other chapters using the procedures. The compositions and preparation of the Service Process Solutions (SPS) used in the procedure are described in Table 202. Each solution is identified by an SPS number. The materials required to make up the process solution are assigned a Service Process Material Control (SPMC) number. Permanent type P3 air filter cleaning and inspection (SPOP U012) is described in Table 203.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: General
procedure.note: The importance of engine cleaning cannot be overstated, for the following reasons:
procedure.step: Permits thorough examination of components for presence of service flaws and loss of dimensions through abrasion and wear.
Removes deposits which adversely affect efficient functioning of engine components.
Prepares surfaces for repair and salvage processes such as plating, welding and painting.

Removes various organic or inorganic coatings which require replacement either for inspection of underlying surfaces or removes deteriorated coating unsuitable for further service. Since one reason for cleaning is to prepare parts for adequate inspection, excessive cleaning should be avoided and the following points kept in mind:

In general, parts subjected to visual inspection only, or to magnetic particle inspection, do not require the high degree of cleanliness necessary for parts subjected to fluorescent penetrant inspection.
Stains on cadmium or nickel-cadmium plated parts need not be removed since they do not impair magnetic particle inspection. Scrubbing such stains may remove the plating and necessitate replating.
Oxide coatings need not be removed unless critical penetrant inspection is required.

Paints and varnishes on non-ferrous parts need not be stripped unless subsequent fluorescent penetrant inspection indicates they cause a fluorescence which interferes with crack detection, or the condition is such that paint or varnish requires replacement.
If Hylomar (PWC09-005) has previously been usedon mating surfaces, and cleaning with applicable SPOP is not effective, use a nylon brush in these areas.

procedure.title: Precautions
procedure.note: To avoid possible damage to costly engine parts, the following points should be noted:
procedure.step: Always refer to appropriate procedure before cleaning any engine part. Some parts can be seriously damaged if an unsuitable cleaning process is used.
Ensure process requirements are met by frequent checking; also temperature and strength of solutions, and immersion time in solutions.
Test cleaning solutions regularly, according to recommended schedule.

After cleaning parts which contain recesses, passageways or enclosed areas, take care to ensure these areas have been thoroughly cleaned out. Damage may result from hydraulic action of residual oil, grease, preservation compound or other liquids trapped in blind holes into which studs, bolts, inserts or similar fittings will be screwed or press-fitted.
Acid-cleaning methods shall not be used where there is any possibility of the cleaning agent becoming entrapped, or not completely removed, during cleaning.
Since they are subject to stress corrosion caused by entrapment of halogen-containing materials, titanium parts must not be processed through tricholorethylene degreasers.

n-para.title: Permanent Type Oil Filter Cleaning and Inspection

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: In a stainless steel container, soak filter element in carbon removing solvent (PWC11-020) for 30 to 60 minutes at room temperature.

Immerse element in cleaning solvent (PWC11-014) or (PWC11-032) in an ultrasonic cleaner (with backflushing adapter and flush filter of 3 to 5 microns) for 1 to 3 minutes at 118 °F (48 °C). Boiling point is (117.6 °F) 47.6 °C. Filter housing may be used as an adapter.
Simultaneously backflush and clean the element at a flow rate of 1 to 3 gal/min at 30 psig. and at an ultrasonic frequency of 25 kHz minimum for 1 to 3 minutes at 100 °F (38 °C).
Rotate the element 180 degrees. Continue to backflush and clean simultaneously at a flow rate 1 to 3 gal/min at 30 psig. for 1 to 3 minutes at 100 °F (38 °C).

Hold element in vapors below water jacket level for 1 to 5 minutes at 118 °F (48 °C). Cooling water should be flowing in a constant stream through water jacket, at not more than 80°F (27 °C), otherwise unnecessary losses of highly volatile solvent (PWC11-014) or (PWC11-032) will occur. Continue to run water through cooling system at least 30 minutes after ultrasonic cleaner is switched off. Temperature of condensed vapors is approximately 100 °F (38 °C).
Drain element above water jacket level 1 to 5 minutes.
Use clean, dry compressed air to dry the element for 1 to 3 minutes.
Inspect the element for lint deposits.
Use clean, dry compressed air and/or plastic or wooden spatula to remove any lint deposits.
Remove any remaining lint deposits by soaking the element in lint dissolving solution for 60 minutes (Ref. Table ).
Flush the element in hot water 150 to 200 °F (66 to 93 °C) for 1 to 5 minutes to remove any remaining lint residue.
Use clean, dry compressed air to dry the element for 1 to 3 minutes.
Swab element end caps with 5 to 10% nitric acid solution (PWC05-195) to remove any copper deposits.
Pressure flush the element with cold water at room temperature.
Use clean, dry compressed air to dry the element for 1 to 3 minutes.
Use a 10 power magnification glass to inspect the element for broken wires. Reject the element if broken wires are found. Sharp and deep dents, if otherwise acceptable, should not be straightened.

Do a bubble point test with the element submerged 1/2 inch below the surface of cleaning solvent (PWC11-014) or (PWC11-032) at 72 °F (22 °C). Rotate the element slowly and smoothly until first air bubble emerges. Reject the element if the bubble point value is less than 8 inches - water gage. Slowly increase the air pressure without creating ambient vibrations.
Use clean, dry compressed air to dry the element for 1 to 3 minutes.
Seal the element in a clean plastic bag.

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: Use the solution described in Table for removing lint deposits from the permanent type P3 air filter.

table.title: SPS U0020 - Lint Dissolving Solution Preparation

n-para.title: Permanent Type P3 Air Filter Cleaning and Inspection

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: In a stainless steel container, soak filter element in carbon removing solvent (PWC11-020) for 15 to 30 minutes at room temperature.
Dip rinse element in hot water 150° to 200 °F (66° to 93 °C) .

Immerse element in cleaning solvent (PWC11-014), (PWC11-032) or (PWC11-055) in an ultrasonic cleaner (with backflushing adapter and flush filter of 3 to 5 microns) for 1 to 3 minutes at 118 °F (48 °C). Boiling point is (117.6 °F) 47.6 °C. Filter housing may be used as an adapter.

Simultaneously backflush and ultrasonic clean the element at a flow rate of 1 to 3 gal/min at 30 psig. and at an ultrasonic frequency 25 kHz minimum for 1 to 3 minutes at 100 °F (38 °C). Boiling point is (117.6 °F) 47.6 °C. Filter housing may be used as an adapter.
Rotate the element 180 degrees. Continue to backflush and ultrasonic clean simultaneously at a flow rate 1 to 3 gal/min at 30 psig. for 1 to 3 minutes at 100 °F (38 °C).

Hold element in vapors below water jacket level for 1 to 5 minutes at 118 °F (48 °C). Cooling water should be flowing in a constant stream through water jacket, at not more than 80°F (27 °C), otherwise unnecessary losses of highly volatile solvent (PWC11-014) or (PWC11-032) will occur. Continue to run water through cooling system at least 30 minutes after ultrasonic cleaner is switched off. Temperature of condensed vapors is approximately 100 °F (38 °C).
Drain element above water jacket level 1 to 5 minutes.
Use clean, dry compressed air to dry the element for 1 to 3 minutes.
Inspect the element for lint deposits.
Use clean, dry compressed air and/or plastic or wooden spatula to remove any lint deposits.
Remove any remaining lint deposits by soaking the element in lint dissolving solution for 60 minutes (Ref. Table ).
Flush the element in hot water 150 to 200 °F (66 to 93 °C) for 1 to 5 minutes to remove any remaining lint residue.
Use clean, dry compressed air to dry the element for 1 to 3 minutes.
Swab element end caps with 5 to 10% nitric acid solution (PWC05-195) to remove any copper deposits.
Pressure flush the element with cold water.
Use clean, dry compressed air to dry the element for 1 to 3 minutes.
Use a 10 power magnification glass to inspect the element for broken wires. Reject the element if broken wires are found. Sharp and deep dents, if otherwise acceptable, should not be straightened.

Do a bubble point test with the element submerged 1/2 inch below the surface of cleaning solvent (PWC11-014), (PWC11-032) or (PWC11-048) at 72 °F (22 °C). Rotate the element slowly and smoothly until first air bubble emerges. Reject the element if the bubble point value is less than 8 inches - water gage. Slowly increase the air pressure without creating ambient vibrations.
Use clean, dry compressed air to dry the element for 1 to 3 minutes.
Seal the element in a clean plastic bag.

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step:
If cleaning of oil tubes specified in applicable chapter is ineffective, then additional cleaning must be carried out as follows: Soak in cold carbon remover compound (PWC11-021) or (PWC11-021A) or (PWC11-021B) for 2 hours at room temperature.
CAREFULLY INSPECT INTERIOR OF EACH TUBE TO MAKE SURE THAT NO PART OF SWAB OR CLOTH IS AVAILABLE, WHICH BLOCKS OIL FLOW.Remove from compound and pull a applicable size swab (or lint free cloth) through tube. Flush fully with petroleum solvent (PWC11-027) at room temperature. Dry with clean, dry, compressed air.

title.xref: SPS U0020 - Lint Dissolving Solution Preparation

general.para: Personnel inspecting engine components should refer to the INTRODUCTION of this manual to familiarize themselves with general overhaul procedures (Ref. Outline of Overhaul Procedures) and P&WA Standard Practices Manual P/N 585005.

Inspection procedures within this manual may refer to the letter prefix SPOP, an abbreviation for Service Process Operation Procedure, which is followed by a control number, e.g. SPOP 62, STANDARD FLUORESCENT PENETRANT INSPECTION. For all SPOP inspection methods, refer to P&WA Overhaul Standard Practices Manual P/N 585005.

Where chapter/section/unit provide specific inspection procedures for engine parts or assemblies, a figure is provided for illustration purposes. To avoid repetitive inspection information on similar parts such as tubes, hoses, bearings, etc., reference will be made to this chapter.

Each component must be carefully inspected by trained specialists who are capable of deciding, when no limits are specified, whether the part is suitable for further service, requires repair or must be replaced with new parts. In addition to visual inspection for surface faults, magnetic particle or fluorescent penetrant inspection must be carried out on specific parts to assist detection of cracks or material defects. If no limits are specified, cracks in any component are cause for its rejection. Where limits for wear or damage are given, it must be understood that these are maximum limits. At the conclusion of magnetic particle inspection, each component must be demagnetized and checked for residual magnetism before being returned to service.

Surface damage in the form of nicks, dents or scratches, which does not exceed the limits specified, shall be removed with a fine stone or abrasive cloth. Local smoothing must extend over an area at least fifteen times the depth of damage. The sharper the damage, the more desirable it is to have the affected area smoothed. Surface finish of all repairs must be as smooth as, or smoother than the original finish, and finish marks must follow the pattern of original machining.

procedure.title: Methods of Life Marking
procedure.step: Service Life of Parts (Hours): The total operating hours (accumulated) of certain engine parts are required for record of warranty purposes. Engine parts in this category are marked at manufacture with a serial number placed on a convenient and, whenever possible, plainly visible surface. Serial numbered engine parts include; combustion chamber liner, main antifriction bearings, etc. Serial numbered engine accessories include; engine-driven pump, fuel control unit, compressor bleed valves, ignition exciter, etc. In order to maintain a complete record of total accumulated operating hours of serial numbered parts, a method such as the Specimen Inspection Record Sheet (Ref. Fig. ) or a card index system, must be established by the facility operator.

Service Life of Parts (Hours/Cycles): The engine-logged service time between overhauls in hours and cycles shall be marked on each life-limited rotor component part listed (Ref. Chapter 05-00-00and 3002). Applicable marking methods to ensure legibility and durability of mark, in a manner that will not affect function or service- ability, are described in P&WA Standard Practices Manual (Ref. 70-11, MARKING OF PARTS).

procedure.title: Engine Main Bearings
procedure.step: Although engine main bearings Nos. 1 through 4 and gearbox second-stage carrier and thrust bearing are retired on condition only. It is considered beneficial to maintain a record of their accumulated hours in either of the following ways: Inspection records, identifying bearings with their serial numbers. Manually vibro-peening accumulated operating hours directly on the bearing adjacent to the serial number; afterwards, lightly stone marked area to remove any raised edges.

n-para.title: Tubes and Hoses
n-para.note: The following information on tubes and hoses is a standard instruction. Specific instructions, where applicable, will be described in the appropriate chapter within the manual:

procedure.title: Tubing
procedure.step: Circumferential scratches in tubes are acceptable provided they do not exceed a 45 degree segment on circumference. Any number of scratches is permissible; these may be blended out provided depth of blend does not exceed one-quarter of the wall thickness of tube.
Longitudinal scratches in tubes must not exceed one-half inch in length. Any number of scratches is permissible.
Nicks and chafing marks in tubes are acceptable provided three-quarters of the wall thickness remains after blending. Each blended area must not exceed one-half square inch.

Dents in tubes are of limited acceptability, provided there are no restrictions to flow caused by sharp edges or corners. Dents are unacceptable within one inch of ferrule scarf-welds, or in a blended area.
Minor isolated pitting is acceptable if not greater than 0.003 inch in depth. Clusters of pits should be blended out to a maximum depth of 0.005 inch.
Rust and stains on tubes are acceptable if they can be removed by light polishing with a very mild abrasive.

procedure.title: Hoses
procedure.step: High pressure hoses that operate at pressures above 150 psig must be rejected if any crimps or buckles are evident. A "crimp" or "buckle" is an abrupt change in the hose liner contour caused when the hose is bent at too small a radius. As a result, the liner will be partially collapsed in one location. This condition, which can be detected without removal of the metal braid, is similar to that which occurs when a cardboard tube is bent. When the affected hose is straightened, the collapsed area will expand but a change in contour remains.

procedure.title: Metal Braid
procedure.step: Hoses with cuts in metal braid, having more than three broken wires per plait, or more than six broken wires per linear foot must be replaced.
Replace flexible hoses on which braid wires have chafed or worn to inner liner with new hoses.

procedure.title: Pressure Test
procedure.step: Test high pressure hoses with hydraulic fluid at 3000 psig. Maintain pressure for a minimum of two minutes.

procedure.title: General
procedure.step: Standard antifriction bearing inspection procedures are described in P&WA Standard Practices Manual (Ref. 70-35, Antifriction Bearing Inspection). The procedures include: general precautions, inspection reports, unpacking new bearings, inspection areas, feel tests, scriber tracing, visual inspection and bearing protection.
No bearing repairs are permitted other than the repairs contained in P&WC approved manuals or the Anti-Friction Bearing Overhaul Inspection Standard P/N 3039731.
In addition to standard procedures, all engine antifriction bearings specified in Table must undergo specific dimensional checks as detailed in the following paragraphs.

procedure.title: Measure Inside and Outside Diameters
procedure.caution: TO ENSURE MAXIMUM ACCURACY WHEN TAKING MEASUREMENTS, ALL PARTS OF A BEARING ASSEMBLY MUST BE AT THE SAME TEMPERATURE. WARMING OF PARTS THROUGH EXCESSIVE HANDLING MUST BE AVOIDED.
procedure.step: Reject bearing if discoloration of bearing due to overheating is dark violet to purple after cleaning (Ref. Anti-Friction Bearing Overhaul Inspection Standard P/N 3039731).
Take three readings of each measurement at three equally spaced positions, and establish arithmetical average for final recorded measurement.

To ensure correct readings, use dial bore gage, or similar gage operating on the air-gap principle; both types of instrument are capable of measuring accurately within 0.0001 inch with a gage force not exceeding four ounces.
Reject any bearing assembly having an ID or OD dimension outside limits specified in Table , for the particular bearing.

entry.note: Refer to Figure 1, INTRODUCTION.
DELETED

n-para.title: Gears and Gearshaft Inspection
n-para.caution: HANDLE COMPONENTS WITH EXTREME CARE. ALWAYS WEAR CLEAN SYNTHETIC RUBBER OR LINT-FREE COTTON GLOVES DURING HANDLING. PROTECT GEARS AND GEARSHAFTS WITH ENGINE OIL AND PLACE IN CLEAN PLASTIC BAG OR CLEAN SUITABLE CONTAINER IF NOT REQUIRED FOR IMMEDIATE USE.
n-para.note: The following general inspection procedures should be used for all gears and gearshafts except where more specific inspection procedures/data are detailed in the relevant chapters of this manual.

procedure.title: Visually Inspect the Gear Teeth
procedure.step: Spalling: Reject if evident.
Surface Pitting: Accept pitting damage up to 0.005 inch deep and 0.010 inch diameter provided no more than five pits are found in 0.250 inch diameter area.
Raised Material and Sharp Edges: Stone to remove.

Localized Nicks, Dents or Scratches: Remove sharp edges and blend damage up to 0.003 inch deep and 0.010 inch wide; provided a minimum 80% of total tooth surface contact pattern remains. Polish to restore original surface finish and maintain tooth profile.

Uneven Tooth Surface Contact Pattern: Damage up to 0.003 inch deep is acceptable, provided a minimum of 80% of the total tooth surface contact pattern remains. Polish to restore original surface finish and maintain tooth profile.

procedure.title: Magnetic Particle Inspect
procedure.step: Inspect gears and gearshafts using appropriate SPOP (Refer to relevant chapter for specific SPOP callout).

procedure.title: Inspect the Carbon Seal Face
procedure.step: Localized Nicks, Dents or Scratches: Damage up to 0.002 inch deep without high spots and not extending across more than 50% of sealing face is acceptable. Lap face if damage exceeds limits.
Runout: Runout must be 0.001 inch FIR in relation to data unless otherwise stated.
Flatness: Flatness must be within two helium light bands. Lap face (Ref. Repair) if flatness exceeds limits.
Surface Finish: Surface finish must be within 4 micro-inches or better.

procedure.title: Inspect the Splines
procedure.step: Surface Pitting: Accepts pitting damage up to 0.005 inch deep by 0.015 inch diameter provided no more than five pits are found in 0.250 inch diameter area.
Raised Material and Sharp Edges: Stone to remove.

Localized Nicks, Dents or Scratches: Remove sharp edges and blend damage up to 0.005 inch deep and 0.010 inch wide, provided a minimum 80% of total spline surface contact pattern remains. Polish to restore original surface finish and maintain spline profile.
Galling: Remove damage up to 0.005 inch deep by polishing to restore original surface finish. Maintain original spline profile.

Wear, Uneven Spline Surface Contact Pattern: Damage up to 0.005 inch deep is acceptable, provided a minimum of 80% of the total spline surface contact pattern remains. Polish to restore original surface finish and maintain spline profile.

procedure.title: Inspect the Threads
procedure.step: Surface Pitting: Accept pitting damage up to 0.003 inch deep by 0.010 inch diameter, provided no more than three pits are found in 0.250 inch length.
Raised Material and Sharp edges: Stone to remove.

Localized Nicks, Dents or Scratches: Remove sharp edges and blend damage up to 0.005 inch deep and 0.010 inch wide, provided a minimum 90% of total thread contact pattern remains. Polish to restore original surface finish and maintain original thread profile.
Galling: Remove damage up to 0.005 inch deep by polishing to restore original surface finish. Maintain original thread profile.
Wear: Damage up to 0.003 inch deep is acceptable.

procedure.title: Inspect Retaining Ring Grooves and Slots
procedure.step: Surface Pitting: Accept pitting damage up to 0.005 inch deep by 0.015 inch diameter, provided no more than five pits are found in 0.250 inch diameter area.
Raised Material and Sharp Edges: Stone to remove.
Localized Nicks, Dents or Scratches: Remove sharp edges and blend damage up to 0.005 inch deep and 0.010 inch wide. Polish to restore original surface finish.
Wear: Damage up to 0.005 inch deep is acceptable.

procedure.title: Inspect Oil Hole(s)
procedure.step: Ensure holes are clean and free of any obstructions.

procedure.title: Inspect Gearshaft Bearing Diameters
procedure.note: The following inspection is for damage on bearing diameter shaving direct contact with balls/rollers of bearing.
procedure.step: DIAMETER(S) IN DIRECT CONTACT WITH BEARING(S) HAVING NO INNER RACE MUST NOT BE PLATED.Surface Pitting: Accept pitting damage up to 0.005 inch deep by 0.015 inch diameter, provided no more than five pits are found in 0.250 inch diameter area.
Raised Material and Sharp Edges: Stone to remove.

Localized Nicks, Dents or Scratches: Remove sharp edges and blend damage up to 0.005 inch deep and 0.010 inch wide, provided damage is 0.050 inch minimum apart. Polish to restore original surface finish and maintain geometric tolerances.

Scratches or Scoring: Remove sharp edges and blend damage up to 0.005 inch deep and 0.010 inch wide, provided damage is 0.050 inch minimum apart. Polish to restore original surface finish and maintain geometric tolerances.

procedure.title: Inspect Remaining Surfaces
procedure.step: Surface Pitting: Accept minor pitting damage up to 0.005 inch deep by 0.015 inch diameter, provided no more than five pits are found in 0.250 inch diameter area.
Raised Material and Sharp Edges: Stone to remove.
Localized Nicks, Dents or Scratches: Remove sharp edges and blend damage up to 0.010 inch deep and 0.010 inch wide. Polish to restore original surface finish and maintain geometric tolerances.

procedure.title: Inspect All Surfaces
procedure.step: Remove surface stains, corrosion deposits up to 0.001 inch deep using SPOP 16. Prior to wet glass bead blasting, mask the following areas: Diameters in direct contact with balls/rollers of bearing. Carbon seal contact face(s). Oil seal(s) diameter(s). Oil hole(s).

subpara.para:
The locking torque of all self-locking nuts and self-locking helical coil inserts shall be checked at each overhaul. This check is necessary to ensure that the self-locking feature still causes a tight frictional hold on the mating threads. The locking torque shall, unless otherwise specified, be not less than that shown in Table . When checking the self-locking torque, care must be taken to ensure the fastener is unseated so that only the torque necessary to overcome the frictional hold on the screw thread is measured. Torque values specified are applicable only when locking torque is checked with a part identical to that with which the nut or insert will mate on reassembly.

title.xref: Minimum Acceptable Locking Torque for Self-locking Nuts and Self-locking Helical Coil Inserts

general.para: Personnel repairing engine components should refer to the Introduction section of this Manual (Ref. Outline of Overhaul Procedures) and P&WA Overhaul Standard Practices Manual P/N 585005).

Specific repairs are provided in certain chapters of the manual; repairs common in many areas of the engine are described in this chapter, e.g. helical coil inserts, oversize stud holes etc. Standard repair should be used where specified.

Many repair procedures refer to the letter prefix SPOP, an abbreviation for Service Process Operation Procedure, which is followed by a control number, e.g. SPOP 21, CADMIUM PLATE. Whenever any repair SPOP method is required, refer to P&WA Overhaul Standard Practices Manual for detailed information.
These instructions assume that all components have been cleaned, inspected and tagged to indicate whether they are suitable for further service, require repair or must be replaced.
Where specific procedures include inspection using either fluorescent penetrant or magnetic particle methods, reference must be made to the appropriate table in Inspection for detailed instructions.

During a repair, if there are no unusual conditions, NDT inspection (FPI or MPI) after a machining operation is optional. Refer to the SPM (Chapters 70-32-00 and 70-33-00) to find the conditions when it is necessary or not, to do these inspections. This is not applicable to rotating parts (Ref. SPM Chapter 70-00).

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.
For alternate products, suppliers, and suppliers addresses, refer to Consumable Materials List P/N 3043340.

subpara.para: Oversize studs are installed as replacements for those parts which are stretched, loose or have damaged threads. Should an oversize stud require replacement, use the next oversize stud. Use the correct stud drivers to insert new studs and torque to values given (Ref. P&WA Standard Practices Manual, Ref. 70-52). The Illustrated Parts Catalog for the engine will provide part numbers and location of studs.

When threads of a stud hole are damaged beyond dimensions suitable for a maximum oversized stud, they may be repaired by using a helical coil insert (Ref. Para. , following). Refer to the Illustrated Parts Catalog for part numbers and locations of suitable helical coil inserts.Before other methods of replacing studs are attempted, e.g. inserts or solid inserts, ensure that sufficient material remains around the repair so as not to impair the integrity of cavity walls, etc.

procedure.title: Repair Damaged Stud Holes
procedure.step: Check that damaged hole is repairable.
Measure core depth of existing hole.
Refer to helical coil manufacturers catalog to determine appropriate insert and tools required to carry out repair.
Select standard drill of appropriate size and drill hole to depth measured in step , preceding.
Using tap specified in catalog, thread hole one thread deeper than insert to be installed.
Where applicable, counterbore to required angle and depth.
Remove all swarf and dust from hole.
If part is magnesium, treat tapped hole as specified on SPOP 41. If part is aluminum, treat in accordance with SPOP 42.
Using inserting tool specified in catalog, screw insert, tang first, into tapped hole to finish 1 to 1-1/2 threads below surface of part or counterbore, whichever applies.
Cut off driving tang using tang break-off tool specified in catalog, and remove tang from hole.
Inspect repaired hole.

procedure.title: Replace Damaged Inserts
procedure.step: Remove unserviceable insert with recommended extracting tool.
Install new insert (Ref. SPOP 415).
Inspect new insert ( Ref. Inspection).

procedure.title: Replace Damaged Loop Clamp Grommets (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Soften cement between grommet and clamp with cleaning solvent (PWC11-022), and remove grommet and all residual cement from clamp.
Roll new grommet around suitable rod to obtain required inside diameter (dia. A). Exercise care when forming loop to avoid damaging grommet.
Wipe mating surfaces of clamp and grommet with clean, lint-free cloth moistened in cleaning solvent (PWC11-022), to ensure clean and dry contact areas for application of cement.
Apply thin film of cement (PWC09-001A) or (PWC09-004) to designated areas on loop clamp and grommet.
Position grommet in loop clamp, align as shown, and press cemented surfaces together. Allow cement to cure for 24 hours at room temperature.
Check adhesion of grommet to loop clamp. If unsatisfactory, repeat steps through .

subpara.title: General
subpara.para: Recommended welding procedures are described in the INTRODUCTION section of this manual, and details of procedures to be followed when welding engine parts are given in 70-42, P&WA Standard Practices Manual.

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: Recommended welding procedures are described in the Introduction sections of this manual, and details of procedures to be followed when welding engine parts are given in 70-42, P&WA Standard Practices Manual..
Unless directed otherwise, stress relief after welding is not required.
A new weld shall not be applied over an existing weld repair.
Weld beads shall be dressed to within 0.005 inch of adjacent parent metal. No undercutting is permissible.
The width of weld bead shall not exceed 0.150 inch at any point.

procedure.title: Determination of Coating (Varnish or Araldite)
procedure.step: Heat component to 48° to 54°C (120° to 130°F ), local heating permitted.
Mix 75 grams of sodium hydroxide (PWC05-057), to a liter of water, heat solution to 120°-130° F and apply a few drops of solution to coating, wait 1-2 minutes. Rub with a cloth.
Varnish will dissolve to show bare metal, Araldite will remain.
Rinse area with cloth soaked in water.
Dry with clean rag and compressed air.

procedure.title: Stripping Surface Sealant (Araldite) Coating from Magnesium Components
procedure.step: Degrease component per SPOP 209.
MAKE SURE STRIPPER IS FREE OF WATER TO AVOID CORROSION OF MAGNESIUM PART.Strip surface sealant (Araldite), epoxy primer and aluminized paint per SPOP 260.
If local spots persist on component, mask as required, and remove by dry plastic blast per SPOP 19.
Touch-up bare metal per SPOP 41. Complete immersion in tank of dichromate solution may be required if the component has been extensively dry plastic blasted to remove the old coating.

procedure.title: Application of Surface Sealant (Araldite) on Magnesium Components
procedure.step: Apply surface sealant per SPOP 173 to total thickness of 0.00025 to 0.00045 inch. Apply masking on studs, pins, helical coil inserts, jacking inserts and internal sleeves per SPOP 36.
Remove masking.

procedure.title: Touch-up of Araldite Coated Components
procedure.note: This touch-up procedure is to be done to reworked areas not exceeding 5% of the total surface of the component. If this limit is exceeded, strip and recoat entire component with Araldite coating per Subparas. and
procedure.step: Degrease component per SPOP 209 or locally degrease reworked area per SPOP 208.
Touch-up bare metal per SPOP 41.
Mask studs, pins, helical coil inserts, jacking inserts and internal sleeves per SPOP 36.

Prepare two-pack epoxy coating (PWC07-037) by mixing one part by volume of resin with one part by volume of catalyst. Coating may be applied by either a brush or spray gun. Use thinner (PWC07-016) as required to obtain proper viscosity for the spray gun.
Bake for 20 minutes minimum at 143° to 154 °C (290° to 310 °F).
Cool down and verify masking at room temperature.
Touch-up component as soon as possible with surface sealant (PWC07-037) to make sure that moisture is not absorbed. Apply one coat (0.0004 to 0.0007 inch).
Air dry for 20 minutes at room temperature.
Bake for one hour at 93° to 121 °C (200° to 250 °F).
Locally restore epoxy primer and aluminized enamel paint on reworked areas per SPOP 148 except, bake enamel paint for 45 minutes at 143° to 149 °C (290° to 300 °F).

procedure.title: Restoration of Anti-friction Compound
procedure.step: Touch up bare metal as necessary per SPOP 41 for magnesium, or SPOP 42 for aluminum.
Mix compound (PWC07-001) until settling is eliminated. In very humid conditions and/or for extra smooth finish, preheat housing to 52° to 66°C (125° to 150°F) for a minimum of 15 minutes.
Apply one coat of compound by spray method, 0.0006 to 0.001 inch thick.
Post cure for 30 minutes minimum at 150 ± 4°C (300 ± 25°F).

procedure.title: Repair Oil Tubes With Dents (Area a, Fig. )
procedure.step: Stainless steel oil tubes with round-bottom dents found in Area a can be repaired as follows. Do not remove ferrules.

Insert a brass rod of the appropriate size into the tube damaged area and secure the other end of the brass rod in a vise or other suitable holder. The brass rod should be the largest diameter that will fit into the tube without damaging the ferrule.

Use a suitable smooth-faced hammer to lightly tap the tube outer wall surface to re-shape the tube to its original shape. Rework the damaged areas of the tube in small increments with light hammer blows. Attempts to rework large areas with single hammer blows could result in the tube being rejected.
Make sure that the ferrule or other areas of the tube were not damaged during rework.
Locally polish the reworked area.
Fluorescent penetrant inspect reworked area per SPOP 62.

COMPRESSED AIR CAN CAUSE SERIOUS INJURY. MAKE SURE THE TUBE IS TESTED IN A MANNER SO THAT PERSONNEL ARE PROTECTED IN THE EVENT OF A TUBE FRACTURE OR FAILURE.Pressure test the tube at 150 to 200 psi. No leakage is permitted.
Clean the tube assembly (Ref. Chapter 79-20-01, CLEANING).

procedure.title: Repair Oil Tubes With Damaged Ferrules or Dents (Area b, Fig. )
procedure.step: Stainless steel oil tubes dented within 0.750 inch from the ferrule (Area b), can be repaired without removing the ferrule, provided that the ferrule is not damaged. If the ferrule is not damaged, rework the tube to remove dents in Area b, (Ref. Para. , steps to ).

Only if the ferrule is damaged, or replacement of it is necessary for access to perform the repair, proceed as follows: Locally heat the ferrule until able to remove it from the tube. Discard the damaged ferrule or retain undamaged ferrule. Strip the remaining silver braze using SPOP 305. Rework the damaged tube to remove dents in Area b (Ref. Para. , steps to . Fluorescent penetrant inspect reworked area per SPOP 62. Prepare ferrule and tube for brazing according to AMS 2664: DO NOT HIGHLY POLISH SURFACES TO BE JOINED. DO NOT USE ALUMINUM OXIDE TYPE ABRASIVES SUCH AS CROCUS CLOTH TO POLISH SURFACES.Lightly clean OD of tube and ID of ferrule with No. 320 grit silicon carbide cloth (PWC05-101). Degrease with (PWC11-009). Apply sufficient flux (PWC05-108) to completely coat joining surfaces. Install new or undamaged ferrule on the tube in its original position. Support the assembled tube in its required length and alignment. Braze the ferrule on the tube according to AMS 2664 using torch-braze (neutral flame) with brazing rod (PWC08-005). Rinse in clean hot water to remove all traces of flux. Inspect brazed area for continuity of braze all around the ferrule.
COMPRESSED AIR CAN CAUSE SERIOUS INJURY. MAKE SURE THE TUBE IS TESTED IN A MANNER SO THAT PERSONNEL ARE PROTECTED IN THE EVENT OF A TUBE FRACTURE OR FAILURE.Pressure test at 150 to 200 psi. No leakage is permitted.
Clean the tube assembly (Ref. Chapter 79-20-01, CLEANING).

figure.title: Repair of Stainless Steel Oil Tube (Typical)

procedure.title: Cleaning (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Clean surface area using isopropyl alcohol (PWC11-014B) (Ref. Fig. ).
Touch up paint on gearbox with epoxy enamel (PWC05-037) per SPOP 155.
Allow to air dry 30 minutes before handling. Do not use any paint that has been prepared 8 hours before.

procedure.title: Identification (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Clean identification area using isopropyl alcohol (PWC11-014B).
Make stencil with appropriate engine serial number.
Prepare epoxy polyamide yellow Mix one part of epoxy base (PWC07-047) and one part of catalyst (PWC07-048).

Apply epoxy polyamide yellow on RGB front case using stencil and cotton swap. Be careful to number orientation. If epoxy polyamide yellow has to be removed, use epoxy thinner (PWC07-049) as a remover before the epoxy polyamide yellow sets. In all cases, use letters at least 1/4 inch high.

title.xref: Repair of Stainless Steel Oil Tube (Typical)

general.para: Personnel engaged in the final assembly of the engine or modules should read the Introduction section of this manual to familiarize themselves with general overhaul procedures (Ref. INTRODUCTION, How to Use this Manual).
Do not allow loop clamps to move cables from their natural contour when tightening attachment bolts, as chafing of cable will result.

Because engines are under a continuing program of improvement in design and manufacture, certain parts or details may change when refinements are introduced by Service Bulletins (SB). These SBs which may affect assemblies, sub-assemblies, accessories, external components and associated parts must be grouped, assembled and installed in accordance with engine model and SB standard from the appropriate chapter of this manual and the IPC.

Final assembly is divided into three sections: FINAL ASSEMBLY-1 through FINAL ASSEMBLY-3.
FINAL ASSEMBLY-1: MAJOR SUBASSEMBLIES
FINAL ASSEMBLY-2 : ACCESSORY COMPONENTS
FINAL ASSEMBLY-3 : EXTERNAL COMPONENTS

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Preparation Before Installation (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Accessory Gearbox to Gas Generator Assembly

procedure.note: The accessory gearbox and gas generator assembly are overhauled to standards detailed in 72-60-00 and 72-30-00, respectively.
procedure.step: Make sure the gas generator assembly in mounted in the stand (Ref. Chapter 72-30-00).
Remove storage protection or sealing materials from rear face of gas generator assembly and front face of accessory gearbox in preparation for final assembly.

Make sure oil transfer adapter is installed on inlet case (Ref. 72-20-00), and that transfer tubes and associated preformed packings are installed correctly on rear face of inlet case and have not been disturbed since final assembly of gas generator assembly.
Make sure non-metallic seal ring (30) is in position on compressor rear hub coupling (1) and that applicable new expander spring is installed in coupling (Ref. 72-30-05, SUB-ASSEMBLY).

For 3277and PT6A-42A Engines: Slowly rotate compressor until hole in compressor hub coupling (1) is at 12 o'clock position. Put new lockball (16) pt6a38-726000-003-0016 1 in hole and pack with petrolatum (PWC06-002) to retain ball during following assembly.
For 3259/3277 and PT6A-42A engines: Make sure that the spacer (23) pt6a38-726000-003-0015 1 is fully installed into the coupling shaft (12).

procedure.title: Installation of Accessory Gearbox on Inlet Case (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install new preformed packings (13) pt6a38-722000-002-0250 1 and (15) pt6a38-722000-002-0260 1 on oil tank center tube (14) pt6a38-722000-002-0240 1 , and insert tube into center bore of inlet case.
Install preformed packing (2) pt6a38-726000-001-0040 1 on spigot of accessory gearbox diaphragm (21).

FOR 3259, 3277 AND PT6A-42A ENGINES, MAKE SURE SPACER (23) IS INSTALLED IN COUPLING SHAFT.Remove coupling shaft holder (PWC32076) and insert puller/pusher tool screw (27) (PWC30373) through rear of gearbox housing at plug (6) location.
Engage screw (27) with coupling shaft (1) and screw body of tool (29) into gearbox housing.

Back off nut (28) of tool sufficiently to allow full forward travel of screw (27), for engagement of coupling shaft (1) with applicable lock ball (16, 3277/PT6A-42A) or
lock pin pt6a38-723005-002-0520 1 (35, 3277) on compressor hub coupling (12).
Install gearbox on inlet case studs and align coupling shaft, oil transfer tubes and oil tank center tube, taking care not to damage preformed packings.

IF 3277/PT6A-42A LOCK BALL BECOMES DISLODGED FROM COMPRESSOR HUB COUPLING, BALL MUST BE RETRIEVED BEFORE ASSEMBLY CONTINUES.Apply firm hand pressure on puller/pusher tool and push coupling shaft (1) fully forward. Then pull tool back slightly to obtain proper engagement of shaft with applicable lock ball (16, 3277/PT6A-42A) or lock pin (35, 3277).

procedure.title: Installation of Retaining Nuts at Flange G (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install engine lifting bracket pt6a38-726000-001-0030 1 with nuts pt6a38-726000-001-0010 3 . Tighten nuts with your hand.
Install flat spacers pt6a38-726000-001-0020 6 at positions 2, 5, 11, 12, 13 and 14 with nuts pt6a38-726000-001-0010 6 . Tighten nuts with your hand.
Install plain washers pt6a38-726000-001-0020 3 at positions 8, 9 and 10 with nuts pt6a38-726000-001-0010 3 . Tighten nuts with your hand.
Install two flat spacers pt6a38-726000-001-0020 2 and electrical connector flat bracket pt6a38-731007-002-0240 1 at position 3 and 4 with nuts pt6a38-726000-001-0010 2 . Tighten nuts with your hand.
Torque all nuts in diametric sequence 32 to 36 lb.in.
Remove puller/pusher tool (Ref. Para. ).

procedure.title: Check of Coupling Shaft Axial Position ( 3259) (Ref. Fig. )

key.def: Gage Pilot - Components of Coupling Gage Tool
Gage Plunger - Components of Coupling Gage Tool
Gage Sleeve - Components of Coupling Gage Tool

procedure.step: Install coupling gage assembly (PWC34061) with gage plunger (5) fully forward in gage pilot (4). Make sure Face A of gage plunger and legs of gage pilot contact end of compressor hub coupling (2). End of gage plunger must be inside of gage pilot. Otherwise, the indication is that coupling shaft spacers (7, 3259) is installed (Ref. Para ).
Slide gage sleeve (6) forward until Face B of sleeve contacts end of coupling shaft (1).
Make sure Face C of gage sleeve (6) is located within step of gage plunger (5), indicating proper engagement of lock ball (3) and coupling shaft (1).
If Face C of gage sleeve is outside of step, the coupling shaft must be repositioned in accordance with Para.
Remove coupling gage from coupling shaft (1).

procedure.title: Check of Coupling Shaft Axial Position ( 3259/3277 and PT6A-42A) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install coupling gage (PWC34061) in coupling shaft (1) with gage plunger (5) fully forward in gage pilot (4). Make sure Face A of gage plunger seats on the coupling shaft spacer (7), and that legs of gage pilot contact end of compressor hub coupling (2). Rotate coupling gage slightly if necessary, with sleeve (6) pin, to guide legs of gage pilot through scallops of coupling shaft spacer. End of gage plunger must be outside of gage pilot. Otherwise, the indication is that coupling shaft spacer (7) is not installed.
Slide gage sleeve (6) forward until Face B contacts rear of coupling shaft (1).
Check that Face C of gage sleeve (6) is located within step of gage pilot (4), indicating proper engagement of lock ball (3) and coupling shaft (1).
If Face C of gage sleeve is outside of step, the coupling shaft must be repositioned in accordance with Para.
Remove coupling gage from coupling shaft (1).

procedure.title: Installation of Lock Insert and Check of Coupling Shaft Axial Position (3277) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install fixture (PWC34060) over puller (PWC34062) and install spring lock insert (9) pt6a38-726000-003-0017 1 on puller, making sure insert engages fixture tangs.
Install assembly through coupling shaft and engage insert into rear hub coupling. Remove fixture and puller.
Install coupling gage (PWC34161) until gage plunger (5) contacts end of spring lock insert (9) inside compressor rear hub coupling (2).
Slide gage sleeve (6) forward until Face B contacts rear of coupling shaft (1).
Check Face C of gage sleeve (6) is located within STEP of gage plunger (5), indicating proper engagement of lock pin (8) and coupling shaft (1).
If Face C of gage sleeve (6) is outside STEP, coupling shaft (1) must be repositioned in accordance with Para.
Remove coupling gage from coupling shaft (1).

procedure.title: Installation of Accessory Gearbox External Parts (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: For 3274: Lubricated and install preformed packing (5) pt6a38-726000-001-0330 1 on access plug (6). Torque plug 150 to 160 lb.in..

For 3274: Lubricated and install preformed packings (5) pt6a38-726000-001-0330 1 , (26) pt6a38-726000-001-0335 1 on oil nozzle plug (25) pt6a38-726000-001-0325 1 . Torque oil nozzle 150 to 160 lb.in..

For 3317: Lubricated and install preformed packings (5) pt6a38-726000-001-0330 1 , (26) pt6a38-726000-001-0335 1 on oil jet nozzle assembly (27) pt6a38-726000-001-0460 1 . Torque oil jet nozzle assembly 150 to 160 lb.in..

If removed, install drain adapter cap (8) on
adapter (7) pt6a38-726000-008-0060 1 . Torque cap 30 to 40 lb.in.
Safety wire (PWC05-089) plug (6) or oil nozzle (25), adapter (7) and cap (8) to locking eye on gearbox housing.
Install preformed packings (17) pt6a38-722000-002-0190 2 on oil transfer tube (18) pt6a38-722000-002-0180 1 ; insert assembly in boss at 7 o'clock position at bottom of inlet case.

procedure.title: Preparation Before Installation (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: The power section and gas generator assembly are overhauled to standards detailed in 72-01-00 and 72-30-00, respectively.
procedure.step: Make sure gas generator assembly is mounted in stand (Ref. Chapter 72-30-00)
Place power section in vertical position in stand.
Locate sling (2) (PWC32073) or (PWC34073) on propeller mounting flange, and engage dowels in flange bolt holes. Secure sling to flange with four socket-head cap screws (1).
Attach hoist to nose ring on sling to take weight of power section, and remove bolts securing mount ring to exhaust duct.
Hoist power section clear of mount ring and stand.
Remove any protective covers installed during overhaul of power section and gas generator assembly.
Make sure gas generator case Flange C, and power section exhaust duct Flange C, are clean, free from nicks, scratches, dents and other potential seal deformaties.
For PT6A-38 and 3337 Engines: smear thin layer of jointing compound (PWC09-005) on exhaust duct flange prior to assembly.
For 3337 and PT6A-42A Engines: install seal ring (8) on gas generator case flange C locating diameter.

procedure.title: Installation of Power Section on Gas Generator Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: MAKE SURE THAT THE GAGE DOES NOT ENTER BETWEEN SEALING RING AND HOUSING FOR MORE THAN AN ARC OF TWO INCH.Check sealing ring contact with mating power turbine stator housing with 0.001 in. feeler gage.
Rotate sealing rings (8) to achieve best sealing position and identify location of joint in sealing ring.

Install sealing ring on shroud housing with joint at the same location as defined by the contact check. Make sure that joints are 180° apart when two sealing rings are used and the pressure side of sealing ring will face towards gas generator case.
Rotate gas generator assembly (5) in stand so that flange C is uppermost.

WHEN LOWERING POWER SECTION, MAKE SURE FLANGE C OF GAS GENERATOR ASSEMBLY AND EXHAUST DUCT ARE PARALLEL AND AXIALLY ALIGNED. IF ASSEMBLIES DO NOT MATE FREELY, DO NOT USE FORCE. INSTEAD, WITHDRAW POWER SECTION AND CHECK FOR CAUSE OF INTERFERENCE.Lower power section carefully into position on gas generator case.

Install bolts (4) pt6a38-723004-001-0210 55 ( 3013) through mating flanges, with bolt heads at rear (down), and secure with self-locking nuts (3) pt6a38-723004-001-0220 55 . Tighten nuts in diametric sequence and torque 36 to 40 lb.in. Wipe off excess jointing compound.

procedure.title: Installation of Retaining Bolt and Nuts at Flange C (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Component Location on Flange A and C

procedure.step: For PT6A-41 3112: Install and secure support bracket pt6a38-731008-001-0240 1 at location 1.
Install and secure T5 thermocouple wiring harness clamps pt6a38-772001-002-0190 2 at location 5 and 8.
For PT6A-41 and PT6A-42: Install and secure governor pneumatic tube clamp bracket pt6a38-731008-001-0135 1 at location 57.
Install and secure scavenge and pressure oil coupling at location indicated.
Rotate gas generator assembly to horizontal position in stand, as required.

title.xref: Accessory Gearbox to Gas Generator Assembly
Component Location on Flange A and C

ata-page-block.pageblock-title: FINAL ASSEMBLY - 2: ACCESSORY AND EXTERNAL COMPONENTS

general.para: Personnel engaged in the final assembly of the engine should read the Introduction sections of this manual to familiarize themselves with general overhaul procedures (Ref. INTRODUCTION, How to Use this Manual).
Refer to Figure 501 for bracket location before finally making any flange joint.
Do not allow loop clamps to move cables from their natural contour when tightening attachment bolts, as chafing of cable will result.

Because engines are under a continuing program of improvement in design and manufacture, certain parts or details may change when refinements are introduced by Service Bulletins (SB). These SBs which may affect assemblies, sub-assemblies, accessories, external components and associated parts must be grouped, assembled and installed in accordance with engine model and SB standard from the appropriate chapter of this manual and the IPC.

Final assembly is divided into three sections: FINAL ASSEMBLY-1 through FINAL ASSEMBLY-3.
FINAL ASSEMBLY-1: ACCESSORY AND EXTERNAL COMPONENTSMAJOR SUBASSEMBLIES
FINAL ASSEMBLY-2: ACCESSORY COMPONENTS
FINAL ASSEMBLY-3: EXTERNAL COMPONENTS

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

row.entry: Socket - Not applicable to PT6A-38 Engines

procedure.title: Install Oil Filter Element, Filter Housing And Check Valve Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.caution: PRIOR TO INSTALLING FILTER ELEMENT IN 3066 FILTER HOUSING, HOLD HOUSING WITH OPEN END UP TO PREVENT CHECK AND BYPASS VALVE FROM SLIDING OUT AND BEING DAMAGED.
procedure.note: Oil filter housing (3104) is machined to overcome the possibility of interference with oil filter cover.
procedure.step: Install new preformed packing (13) pt6a38-792002-001-0230 pt6a38-792002-001-0330 1 in groove at inner end of oil filter housing (12) pt6a38-792002-001-0200 pt6a38-792002-001-0320 1 .
Install plastic ring (11) pt6a38-792002-001-0150 1 in inner section of groove at center of housing.
Install preformed packing (10) pt6a38-792002-001-0140 1 in outer section of groove, against plastic ring (11).

Install new preformed packings (2) pt6a38-792002-001-0080 1 and (4) pt6a38-792002-001-0060 1 on filter element (3) pt6a38-792002-001-0070 1 . On 3066 engines: Oil filter element (3108) may be replaced with an element (3108) having a finer mesh, to improve oil filtration in sandy or dusty environments.
Install filter element perforated flanged end first, in filter housing (12).

Insert filter housing assembly into compressor inlet case and, applying a gentle hand pressure on end of filter element to maintain check and bypass valve seated in inner end of housing, push assembly into inlet case until firmly seated. Do not apply side loads on housing while it is being pressed into inlet case.

Install new preformed packing (5) pt6a38-792002-001-0050 1 on filter cover (7) pt6a38-792002-001-0010 1 . Ensure stepped spacer (6) is in position and secure on lugs of filter cover. It is recommended that aluminum alloy filter cover (3107) be replaced with a steel cover (3107) to reduce the possibility of oil leaks.

Install filter cover on compressor inlet case and secure with four plain washers (9) pt6a38-792002-001-0030 4 and self-locking nuts (8) pt6a38-792002-001-0020 4 . Tighten nuts and torque 32 to 36 lb.in.

figure.title: Oil Filter Element, Filter Housing and Check Valve Assembly

key.def: Oil Filter Housing and Check Valve Assembly (3066)Oil Filter Housing and Check Valve Assembly (3066)

procedure.title: Install Fuel Pump in Accessory Gearbox (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Remove protective caps from inlet and outlet ports. Depreservation of fuel system is performed prior to engine test. It may be more convenient to preassemble fuel pump to fuel control unit (Ref. Para. ) on the bench, then install units together on engine.
Install gasket (5) pt6a38-731002-001-0110 1 on mounting pad studs of accessory gearbox (6).

ENSURE THAT PUMP DRIVE COUPLING (3139) IS CORRECTLY SECURED ON PUMP SPLINES BY LIGHTLY PULLING AND PUSHING BY HAND. COUPLING (3139) INCORPORATES A STOP FLANGE THAT ELIMINATES THE REQUIREMENT FOR THE OUTER RETAINING RING, AND SHOULD NOT MOVE IN OR OUT. PUMP (3148) INCORPORATES A MODIFIED SPUR GEAR SHAFT FOR MORE POSITIVE LOCKING ACTION WITH THE DRIVE COUPLING. IF NEW PUMP IS INSTALLED, ENSURE THAT ALL GREASE IS REMOVED FROM COUPLING SPLINES.Lightly smear splines of pump drive coupling with clean engine lubricating oil (PWC03-001), ensure oil mist lubrication hole in accessory gearbox fuel control drive gearshaft is not blocked.

ENSURE PUMP COUPLING IS NOT DISPLACED OR MISALIGNED DURING ASSEMBLY. DO NOT APPLY FORCE TO ENGAGE WITH FUEL CONTROL DRIVE GEARSHAFT.Install pump pt6a38-731002-001-0010 1 to boss (6) on accessory gearbox. Engage splined shaft with driveshaft and locate on studs. Secure with three plain washers (4) pt6a38-731002-001-0030 3 and self-locking nuts (3) pt6a38-731002-001-0020 3 . Torque nuts 75 to 85 lb.in.
Carry out functional check at engine testing (Ref. Testing).

key.def: Fuel Pump to Fuel Control Unit Flexible Hose
Fuel Transfer Tube to Oil to Fuel Heater (Pre-SB3395)
Fuel Transfer Tube to Oil to Fuel Heater (Post-SB3395)

procedure.title: Fuel Control Unit (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: With fuel control unit overhauled and assembled to Chapter 73-20-00, proceed as follows: Before installing fuel control unit, remove blanking caps and drain off any preservation fluid. Full depreservation of fuel system is performed prior to engine testing and is detailed in engine test procedure (Ref. Testing). Install new coupling (8) pt6a38-732000-001-0040 1 on fuel control unit pt6a38-732000-001-0010 pt6a38-732000-001-0011 pt6a38-732000-001-0012 pt6a38-732000-001-0013 pt6a38-732000-001-0014 pt6a38-732000-001-0015 pt6a38-732000-001-0016 1 . Install preformed packing (9) pt6a38-732000-001-0050 1 in recess on pump face. Install fuel control unit to pump, engage with coupling (8) and locate on studs in pump. Secure with plain washers (6) pt6a38-732000-001-0030 4 and self-locking nuts (5) pt6a38-732000-001-0020 4 . Tighten nuts and torque 75 to 85 lb.in. Serrated spacer (10) pt6a38-732000-001-0120 1 , fuel control arm (11) pt6a38-732000-001-0110 1 and arm extension (12) pt6a38-732000-001-0100 1 remain loosely assembled at this stage. For final assembly and adjustment, refer to Final Assembly-3. Carry out functional check and adjust at engine testing (Ref. Testing).

procedure.title: Oil-to-Fuel Heater (3009) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install oil-to-fuel heater, overhauled and assembled to Chapter 73-10-01, as follows: Before installing oil-to-fuel heater, remove blanking caps and drain off any preservation fluid from oil and fuel ports. Fuel depreservation of fuel system is performed prior to engine testing and is detailed in engine test procedure (Ref. Testing). Remove blanking caps from transfer tubes (8) pt6a38-731001-002-0080 pt6a38-731001-001-0080 1 or
(25) pt6a38-731001-002-0080 pt6a38-731001-001-0080 and (10) pt6a38-731001-002-0100 pt6a38-731001-001-0100 1 , ensure that tube bores are clean and install two of each preformed packings (9) pt6a38-731001-002-0090 pt6a38-731001-001-0090 2 and (11) pt6a38-731001-002-0110 pt6a38-731001-001-0110 2 on respective tubes. For Pre-SB3395 engines insert fuel outlet transfer tube (8) into orifice in underside of fuel pump, taking care not to displace or damage preformed packing, and secure with upper
retaining plate (6) pt6a38-731001-002-0065 pt6a38-731001-001-0065 1 and two bolts (7) pt6a38-731001-002-0070 pt6a38-731001-001-0070 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 32 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) to retaining plate. For Post-SB3395 engines insert fuel outlet transfer tube (25) into orifice in underside of fuel pump, taking care not to displace or damage preformed packing, and secure retaining plate with two bolts (7) pt6a38-731001-002-0070 pt6a38-731001-001-0070 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 32 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) to retaining plate. Insert oil inlet transfer tube (10) into orifice in accessory gearbox, taking care not to displace or damage preformed packing. Install bracket (18) pt6a38-731001-002-0190 pt6a38-731001-001-0190 1 in fork of bracket (15) pt6a38-731001-002-0180 pt6a38-731001-001-0180 1 , insert pin (12) pt6a38-731001-002-0200 pt6a38-731001-001-0200 1 and retain with washer (13) pt6a38-731001-002-0210 pt6a38-731001-001-0210 1 and cotterpin (14) pt6a38-731001-002-0210 pt6a38-731001-001-0210 1 . Locate bracket assembly on accessory gearbox and secure with two bolts (16) pt6a38-731001-002-0230 pt6a38-731001-001-0230 2 and plain washers (17) pt6a38-731001-002-0240 pt6a38-731001-001-0240 2 . Tighten bolts, and torque 32 to 36 lb.in. Lockwire (PWC05-089) bolts together. Remove blanking caps from
elbow (21) pt6a38-731001-002-0120 1 and
transfer tube (19) pt6a38-731001-002-0160 1 ; ensure that bores are clean. Install preformed packing (22) pt6a38-731001-002-0150 1 on elbow and two preformed packings (20) pt6a38-731001-002-0170 2 on transfer tube (19). Remove blanking plug from oil outlet port of oil-to-fuel heater (1) pt6a38-731001-002-0010 pt6a38-731001-001-0010 1 . Assemble elbow (21) on one end of transfer tube (19) and insert other end of tube into oil outlet port of oil-to-fuel heater (1). Ensure that preformed packings (20) are not displaced or damaged during this operation. Install heater (1) to engine and engage transfer tubes (8) or (25) and (10) with respective ports, and elbow (21) with boss on compressor inlet case. Ensure that preformed packings are not displaced or damaged during this operation. Align holes in mounting lugs of oil-to-fuel heater with corresponding holes in flange G on engine and secure heater with washers (3) pt6a38-731001-002-0030 pt6a38-731001-001-0030 2 and bolts (2) pt6a38-731001-002-0020 pt6a38-731001-001-0020 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 36 to 40 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089). Secure heater (1) to bracket (18) with bolt (16) pt6a38-731001-002-0230 pt6a38-731001-001-0230 1 and washer (17) pt6a38-731001-002-0240 pt6a38-731001-001-0240 1 . Tighten bolt, torque 32 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) to bracket. Secure elbow (21) to boss on oil tank with two washers (23) pt6a38-731001-002-0140 2 and bolts (24) pt6a38-731001-002-0130 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 32 to 36 lb. in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) two bolts together. Position
lower retaining plate (6) pt6a38-731001-002-0060 pt6a38-731001-001-0060 1 around fuel outlet transfer tube (8) or (25) and secure to heater (1) with two bolts (7) pt6a38-731001-002-0070 pt6a38-731001-001-0070 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 32 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) to retaining plate. Ensure drain plug (4) and preformed packing (5) are fitted and torqued 65 to 70 lb.in., and lockwired (PWC05-089) to heater.

procedure.title: Oil-to-Fuel Heater (3009) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install oil-to-fuel heater, overhauled and assembled to Chapter 73-10-01, as follows: Before installing oil-to-fuel heater, remove blanking caps and drain off any preservation fluid from oil and fuel ports. Fuel depreservation of fuel system is performed prior to engine testing and is detailed in engine test procedure (Ref. Testing). Remove blanking caps from transfer tubes (8) pt6a38-731001-002-0080 pt6a38-731001-001-0080 1 or
(25) pt6a38-731001-002-0080 pt6a38-731001-001-0080 and (10) pt6a38-731001-002-0100 pt6a38-731001-001-0100 1 , ensure tube bores are clean and install two of each preformed packings (9) pt6a38-731001-002-0090 pt6a38-731001-001-0090 2 and (11) pt6a38-731001-002-0110 pt6a38-731001-001-0110 2 on respective tubes. For Pre-SB3395 engines insert fuel outlet transfer tube (8) into orifice in underside of fuel pump, taking care not to displace or damage preformed packing, and secure with
retaining plate (6) pt6a38-731001-002-0065 pt6a38-731001-001-0065 1 and two bolts (7) pt6a38-731001-002-0070 pt6a38-731001-001-0070 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 32 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) to retaining plate. For Post-SB3395 engines insert fuel outlet transfer tube (25) into orifice in underside of fuel pump, taking care not to displace or damage preformed packing, and secure retaining plate with two bolts (7) pt6a38-731001-002-0070 pt6a38-731001-001-0070 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 32 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) to retaining plate. Insert oil inlet transfer tube (10) into orifice in accessory gearbox, taking care not to displace or damage preformed packing. Install bracket (18) pt6a38-731001-002-0190 pt6a38-731001-001-0190 1 in fork of bracket (15) pt6a38-731001-002-0180 pt6a38-731001-001-0180 1 , insert pin (12) pt6a38-731001-002-0200 pt6a38-731001-001-0200 1 and retain with washer (13) pt6a38-731001-002-0210 pt6a38-731001-001-0210 1 and cotterpin (14) pt6a38-731001-002-0210 pt6a38-731001-001-0210 1 . Locate bracket assembly on accessory gearbox and secure with two bolts (16) pt6a38-731001-002-0230 pt6a38-731001-001-0230 2 and plain washers (17) pt6a38-731001-002-0240 pt6a38-731001-001-0240 2 . Tighten bolts, and torque 32 to 36 lb.in. Lockwire (PWC05-089) bolts together. Remove blanking plug from oil outlet port of oil-to-fuel heater (1) pt6a38-731001-002-0010 pt6a38-731001-001-0010 1 . Install heater (1) to engage transfer tubes (8) or (25) and (10) with respective ports in heater. Ensure preformed packings are not displaced or damaged during this operation. Align holes in mounting lugs of oil-to-fuel heater with corresponding holes in flange G on engine and secure heater with washers (3) pt6a38-731001-002-0030 pt6a38-731001-001-0030 2 and bolts (2) pt6a38-731001-002-0020 pt6a38-731001-001-0020 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 36 to 40 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089). Secure heater (1) to bracket (18) with bolt (16) pt6a38-731001-002-0230 pt6a38-731001-001-0230 1 and washer (17) pt6a38-731001-002-0240 pt6a38-731001-001-0240 1 . Tighten bolt, torque 32 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) to bracket. Position lower retaining plate (6) pt6a38-731001-002-0060 pt6a38-731001-001-0060 1 around fuel outlet transfer tube (8) or (25) and secure to heater (1) with two
bolts (7) pt6a38-731001-002-0070 pt6a38-731001-001-0070 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 32 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) to retaining plate. Ensure drain plug (4) and preformed packing (5) are fitted and torqued 65 to 70 lb.in., and lockwired (PWC05-089) to heater.

procedure.title: Installation of Thermostatic Bypass and Check Valve (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
With the thermostatic bypass and check valve overhauled and assembled to Chapter 79-20-03, proceed as follows: Install two new
preformed packings (9) pt6a38-731001-001-0170 pt6a38-792003-001-0210 1 on short transfer tube (10) pt6a38-792003-001-0220 1 and insert one end of tube into oil inlet boss on
valve housing (5) pt6a38-792003-001-0060 1 . To facilitate subsequent mating to the oil-to-fuel heater, one end of tube must be moved into the cavity of the valve housing. Install new preformed packing (3) pt6a38-792003-001-0070 1 on valve housing oil outlet boss. Insert oil outlet boss of valve into mating boss at 5 o'clock position on compressor inlet case and secure with two bolts pt6a38-792003-001-0030 2 and washers pt6a38-792003-001-0020 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 36 to 40 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089). Withdraw short transfer tube from cavity in valve housing (5) and insert rear end of tube into mating boss of oil-to-fuel heater (11). ENSURE THAT RETAINING PLATE (6) IS INSTALLED IN LOCATING GROOVE OF TRANSFER TUBE.Install retaining plate (6) pt6a38-792003-001-0230 1 in groove at front end of transfer tube and secure to valve housing with two bolts pt6a38-792003-001-0170 2 , Tighten bolts, torque 36 to 40 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089) to hole in plate.
