general.warning: PERSONNEL HANDLING ENGINES OR ENGINE COMPONENTS REMOVED FROM AGRICULTURAL AIRCRAFT MUST EXERCISE EXTREME CARE TO AVOID PHYSICAL CONTACT WITH SURFACES THAT MAY BE CONTAMINATED BY HIGHLY TOXIC OR CORROSIVE CHEMICALS. USE PROTECTIVE CLOTHING AND BREATHING EQUIPMENT OR DISPOSABLE FACIAL MASKS AT ALL TIMES UNTIL COMPONENTS ARE SATISFACTORILY DECONTAMINATED BY WATER WASHING. SIMILARLY, TAKE CARE IN DISPOSAL OF ANY PACKAGING, CONTAINERS OR CLEANING MATERIALS FOR ENGINES OR COMPONENTS THAT MAY BE CONTAMINATED. INCINERATION IS ADVISED.
general.para: Special handling, packing, storage and preservation procedures for individual components or subassemblies are described, where necessary, in Storage Instructions of the appropriate Chapter.

This section provides information and procedures necessary for storage, preservation and depreservation of an engine, and includes handling instructions for removing an engine from, or installing it into, its fiberboard container, metal container or stand.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Fiberboard Shipping Container
procedure.step: The fiberboard shipping container comprises a wooden skid base, to which is secured a metal cradle, a fiberboard sleeve forming the sides of the container, and a fiberboard cover. Plywood sheeting provides additional support to the container sides and cover. Engine protection within the container is provided by a protective thermoplastic envelope which is evacuated of air and sealed. The base, plywood supports and associated hardware are reusable subject to condition; the fiberboard sections are disposable.

The container, which must not be used for outdoor storage or exposed to climatic conditions for more than one week, is intended for domestic shipment in a closed conveyance on the North American continent, or for overseas shipment by air.
For engine shipping container leading particulars refer to Table following:

procedure.title: Metal Storage and Shipping Container
procedure.step: The metal storage and shipping container is of steel construction and is manufactured in two halves joined at the horizontal center line. A gasket between the upper and lower halves forms a hermetic seal. The metal container is reusable and may be used for long term indoor and outdoor storage, provided the humidity level within the container is frequently checked, the desiccant replenished as required, and the engine preserved in accordance with the preservation schedule (Ref. Para. ).

The metal container is not pressurized. An automatic pressure-activated, two-way breather valve is fitted to the service receptacle to maintain the pressure within the container at or near the prevailing ambient pressure. The breather valve operates whenever internal pressure exceeds ambient pressure by plus 2.0 to 2.5 psi or minus 1.0 to 1.5 psi. The service receptacle cover and service receptacle can be removed to provide access to the desiccant cage for desiccant replenishment. A rectangular recess, at the other end of the container, provides storage for the engine log book, shipping instructions and other documents.

For metal storage and shipping container data, refer to Table following. Metal Storage and Shipping Container, Leading Particulars
DESCRIPTIONDATA
Length90.76 in. (2300 mm)
Width34.0 in. (864 mm)
Height39 in. (990 mm)
Weight400 lb (181.4 kg)
Pressure Tested at10 psig
Material Specification (Skin)SAE 1010 - 1020

procedure.title: Humidity Control
procedure.step: To maintain internal moisture conditions at a safe level for storage, a specific quantity of dehydrating material (desiccant) (Ref. IPC)is stowed in each type of container. The desiccant is packed in individual bags, each containing eight units (one unit weighing one ounce.

Each container has a humidity indicator (Ref. IPC) to show the moisture level within the container without disturbing the container or the contents. At a safe moisture level (up to 40 percent relative humidity) the indicator color is blue.

If the internal humidity increases, the color gradually changes to pink. An all-pink color indicates an unsafe moisture condition, and the desiccant must be replaced with freshly activated material. Humidity indicators have a reversible element allowing them to be reactivated and reused, provided the original all-blue color is evident. Indicators need not be replaced unless damaged.
Twelve bags of desiccant are used in an engine container, and eight bags in a module container.

procedure.title: Reactivation of Desiccant
procedure.step: Place bags of used desiccant and a pink humidity indicator in a suitable oven controlled at 121°C (250°F), until humidity indicator turns blue.
Allow oven to cool to room temperature, approximately 22°C (72°F), then remove bags and indicator.

DO NOT REMOVE DESICCANT BAGS FROM PROTECTIVE POLYETHYLENE ENVELOPES UNTIL REQUIRED FOR INSERTION IN SHIPPING CONTAINERS.As soon as possible, after reactivation is complete, insert bags of desiccant into polyethylene envelopes. Exclude all air and seal envelopes.

procedure.title: Storage of Engine
procedure.step: Fiberboard Container Short term storage of engine can be accomplished in a fiberboard container, under dry conditions, up to six months. A periodic check must be carried out at least once every seven days to prevent humidity from reaching an unsafe level. When indicator changes to a partially pink color, remove engine from container and protective envelope (Ref. Para. ). Replace desiccant with bags of freshly activated desiccant, and reinstall engine in container (Ref. Para. ).

Metal Container When an engine is stored in a metal container, the color of the humidity indicator should be checked every seven to fifteen days, dependent upon the ambient relative humidity. For removal of defective humidity indicator, refer to Para. and for installation of humidity indicator, refer to Para.

procedure.title: Stacking Engine Containers for Storage
procedure.step: Instructions in Tables and must be complied with when stacking engine containers with or without engines

row.entry: Ensure containers are sound and in undamaged condition
Only static (no impact) and superimposed stacking is recommended. Avoid dropping containers on each other.
Replace used sleeve with new sleeve and cover.
Ensure wooden side stiffeners are sound and undamaged.
Only static (no impact) and superimposed stacking is recommended. Avoid dropping containers on each other.

n-para.title: Removal of Engine from Fiberboard Container

procedure.title: Precautions
procedure.step: Ensure a hoist of sufficient lifting capacity plus safety factor is available to lift the following loads: 475 lb (215 kg) engine only. 800 lb (362 kg) engine loaded in fiberboard container.
Ensure container is correctly positioned on floor directly beneath hoist.
Ensure that a clear overhead space of at least eight feet, not including distance from top of container to hoist hook, is available.

procedure.title: Procedure (Ref. Fig. and )
procedure.step: Cut and remove steel strapping (3, Fig. ) from around fiberboard container. Retain reinforcing corners (2). Remove cover (1) and sleeve (5) from base (9). Remove and retain plywood supports (4) and (14) from sleeve and cover.
Cut protective envelope (11) and expose top of engine.

NEVER USE ENGINE SLING AND HOIST FITTINGS TO LIFT AN ENGINE STILL ATTACHED TO THE SKID BASE.Attach sling (1, Fig. ) (PWC32420) or (PWC50066) or (PWC51861-600) to engine lifting brackets (2) and (3) at flanges A and G ensuring lifting eye of sling is adjusted for a level lift.
Take weight of engine on sling, remove three lanyard-attached engine mount pins (5) securing engine to cradle (8).
Raise engine in level attitude until clear of cradle.

Remove two engine front mount brackets (7), one engine mount rear bracket (10) and associated hardware from engine. Retain engine mounts, cradle, skid base and associated hardware for reuse. Remove protective envelope (4).
Replace two engine front mount brackets (7) and engine rear mount bracket (10) on cradle and secure with lanyard-attached engine mount pins (5).
Remove ignition exciter (complete in protective envelope (11)) from cradle. Send exciter for overhaul (Ref. 74-10-00).

Remove 12 desiccant bags from engine and retain for reactivation and reuse. Retain desiccant bag in ignition exciter container until unit is required for use. When unit is removed, desiccant bag should be reactivated for reuse.
Remove shipping data envelopes and envelope containing engine log book from box glued to skid base.

figure.title: Removal/Installation of Engine from Fiberboard Container

n-para.title: Removal of Engine from Metal Container (Ref. Fig. )

procedure.title: Precautions
procedure.step: Equalize pressure between inside and outside of container as follows:
Remove nuts securing service receptacle cover (15) to container base (3) and remove cover.
Release any pressure within container by operating manual release button on breather valve (17).

Ensure that a hoist of sufficient lifting capacity and safety factor is available to lift the following loads: 475 lb (215 kg) engine or container cover. 1500 lb (680 kg) metal container complete with engine.
Position container or engine correctly on floor, directly beneath hoist.
Ensure a clear overhead space of at least eight feet is available, not including distance from top of container to hoist hook.

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: Ensure pressures inside and outside of container are equal (Ref. Subpara. , preceding).
Remove 40 nuts (19), lockwashers (20) and bolts (24) securing container top cover (2) to container base (3).
Lift container top cover (2) using hoist attached to lifting points (1), until cover is free of locating pins (21), and swing clear of engine.
Traverse container cover and lower to rest on clean wooden blocks.
Attach engine sling (2, Fig. ) to front and rear lifting brackets (1 and 3) at flanges A and G, respectively.

NEVER USE ENGINE SLING AND HOIST FITTINGS TO LIFT AN ENGINE STILL ATTACHED TO THE METAL CONTAINER BASE.Take weight of engine on sling, and withdraw two lanyard-attached pins (4) from engine front mount brackets (15).
Withdraw lanyard-attached pin from engine rear mount bracket (5).
Raise engine slowly from container. Ensure engine remains horizontal and does not swing.

Remove two engine front mount brackets (15) and single rear mount bracket (5), bolts and washers (6 and 14) from engine mount pads. Place brackets, bolts and washers in suitable cloth or polyethylene bag, and secure to cradle.
Remove eight desiccant bags from desiccant cage (10) and retain for reactivation and reuse (Ref. Para. ).
Remove two butterfly nuts (6, Fig. ) and log book recess cover (5). Withdraw engine log book and any other documents from container. Replace cover and butterfly nuts.

Remove bolts, washers and self-locking nuts securing ignition exciter (12, Fig. ) to cradle. Remove ignition exciter and retain with engine. Place nuts, washers and bolts in suitable cloth or polyethylene bag and secure to cradle.
Remove all shipping covers, caps and plugs from engine. Place covers, caps and plugs in suitable cloth or polyethylene bag, and secure bag to cradle.
Clean interior of container.
Replace top cover and secure with 40 nuts (19, Fig. ), lockwashers (20) and bolts (24).
Coat all exposed hardware with preservative oil (PWC05-077) or (PWC05-077A) or (PWC05-077B).
Retain moisture barrier/protective wrapping on engine air inlet screen until engine is to be disassembled.

figure.title: Metal Storage and Shipping Container Components

n-para.title: Installation of Engine in Overhaul Stand

procedure.title: Engine Mounting Brackets
procedure.step: Because the overhaul stand (PWC34300) or (PWC51140) or (PWC70907) can be used for engine disassembly, assembly and preparation for testing, it is necessary to select the correct type of mounting brackets as follows: Engine Assembly in Stand/Preparation for Engine Testing: Four independent mounting brackets, incorporating anti-vibration pads (PWC32080), secure the engine to a mounting ring (PWC32081). This mounting ring is bolted to adapters (PWC32052) or (PWC34752) attached to the overhaul stand. It is more expedient to use the above brackets for engine assembly when engine testing in a test cell. Engine Disassembly: Two mounting brackets (PWC71416) are bolted to adapters on the overhaul stand. These brackets can also be used for engine assembly.
Installation procedures for each type of mounting bracket are described in paragraphs and following.

procedure.title: Installation of Engine for Testing and/or Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: With engine suspended from sling (11), fit four mounting brackets (7) to the mounting pads at the 2, 4, 8 and 10 o'clock positions on the engine. Secure each bracket with four bolts (18). Torque bolts 225 to 250 lbs.in.
Secure one engine mount adapter (1) to inner face of each mounting disk on engine stand (15) with four bolts (2), washers (3) and nuts (4).
Secure the bottom (larger) section of the mount ring (10) to adapters (1) with four bolts (5) and washers (6).

Position the stand under the suspended engine and carefully lower until the bottom two engine mounting brackets (7) are aligned with support blocks on bottom section of mount ring. Secure by inserting bolts (16) through brackets and mount ring and fitting washers (19) and nuts (20). Do not tighten or lock nuts at this stage and ensure that engine weight is taken on sling (11).

Install the top (smaller) section of the mount ring (10) on the two top engine mounting brackets (7). Insert bolts (16) through brackets and mount ring and fit washers (19) and nuts (20). Do not tighten or lock nuts at this stage.
Secure the top section of mount ring to lockplates (9) on the bottom section with bolts (8).
Tighten mounting bolts (16) with nuts (20); torque nuts to 50 lb.in. and lock with cotter pins (21).
Ensure hub locking pin (14) is firmly in place, then release engine weight from sling. Remove sling.

procedure.title: Installation of Engine for Disassembly and/or Assembly (Ref. Fig.)
procedure.step: With engine suspended from sling (8), secure left-hand mounting bracket (12) to mounting pads at 8 and 10 o'clock positions on engine using eight bolts (11). Tighten and torque bolts 225 to 250 lb.in.
Secure right-hand mounting bracket (5) to mounting pads at 2 and 4 o'clock position on engine using eight bolts (11). Tighten and torque bolts 225 to 250 lb.in.
Secure one engine mount adapter (3) to inner face of each mounting disk on engine stand (15) with four bolts (4), washers (2) and nuts (1).
Position the stand under the suspended engine and carefully lower engine until holes in adapters (3) align with those is mounting brackets (12) and (5). Secure with bolts (7) and washers (6).
Ensure hub locking pin (14) is firmly in place, then release engine weight from sling. Remove sling.

n-para.title: Preservation/Depreservation of Engine
n-para.note: Depreservation is a preliminary step before engine check run and, when necessary, before disassembly and overhaul.

procedure.title: Engine Check Run
procedure.step: Fill oil tank with approved engine oil (Ref. 72-00-00, TESTING). The lubrication system does not require depreservation.
Connect test cell fuel supply to engine fuel inlet.
Disconnect fuel line at inlet of flow divider and dump valve and direct it into a suitable container.
Set controls as follows: Facility fuel supply valve open, fuel pump switch ON. Ignition switch OFF Propeller control lever at FEATHER. Power control lever at TAKE-OFF.

OBSERVE STARTER MOTOR OPERATING LIMITS. REFER TO STARTER MANUFACTURERS MANUAL.Motor engine, retard power control lever to IDLE, then advance to TAKEOFF. Repeat as necessary until clean fuel flows from open line.
Move power control lever to FUEL CUT OFF, switch fuel supply pump OFF and close facility fuel valve.
Reconnect and secure fuel line to flow divider.
Drain engine oil system (Ref. Disassembly).

subpara.title: Preservation of Engine
subpara.para: The engine fuel and oil systems are preserved preparatory to storage in containers, subject to the conditions detailed in Paragraph . The procedures are described in Subparagraphs and following.

procedure.title: Engine Fuel System Preservation
procedure.caution: EXTREME CARE MUST BE TAKEN TO PREVENT FOREIGN MATERIAL FROM BEING DRAWN INTO ENGINE FUEL SYSTEM. EQUIPMENT MUST BE SUPPLIED WITH SUITABLE FILTER NO COARSER THAN 10 MICRON RATING.
procedure.step: Connect suitable oil supply line to oil-to-fuel heater fuel inlet.
Disconnect fuel line at inlet to flow divider to prevent oil from entering fuel manifold, loosen line as required to permit drainage into a suitable container.

UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES PERMIT PRESERVATION OIL TO ENTER ENGINE WHERE IT MAY COME INTO CONTACT WITH THERMOCOUPLE PROBE ASSEMBLY, OIL CONTAMINATION OF PROBE MAY CAUSE COMPLETE FAILURE OF THERMOCOUPLE SYSTEM.Supply preservative oil (PWC05-077) at 5 to 25 psig at 16°C (60°F) through oil supply line to engine.
Ensure ignition switch is OFF.
Move power control lever to TAKEOFF and condition lever to FLIGHT-IDLE.
OBSERVE STARTER MOTOR OPERATING LIMITS, REFER TO STARTER MANUFACTURERS MANUAL.Motor engine and place the power control lever to IDLE and then TAKEOFF.
After motoring run, check preservative oil is flowing from open fuel line. If not, repeat step until oil flow appears.
Return power control lever to IDLE and condition lever to OFF.
Reconnect fuel line to flow divider and secure line attachment points.
Disconnect oil supply line to oil-to-fuel heater inlet and fit blanking cap to inlet.

procedure.title: Engine Oil System Preservation
procedure.caution: OBSERVE STARTER MOTOR OPERATING LIMITS. REFER TO STARTER MANUFACTURERS MANUAL.
procedure.step: With ignition OFF and condition lever at SHUTOFF, motor engine with starter until oil pressure and compressor speed (Ng) are indicated. Disengage starter.

Place suitable container under engine and remove drain plugs from oil tank and accessory gearbox. Remove chip detector from propeller reduction gearbox. Drain oil from oil tank, accessory and reduction gearboxes.

LIMIT ENGINE MOTORING TO SHORTEST POSSIBLE PERIOD, CONSISTENT WITH COMPLETION OF DRAINING, TO MINIMIZE ENGINE OPERATION WITH LIMITED LUBRICATION.With drains open, motor engine with starter to permit scavenge pumps to clear engine (indicated by cessation of steady oil stream from drains) then disengage starter.
Remove oil filter element.
Allow oil to drain from engine until oil drip is slow and intermittent (allow approximately one-half hour to drain), install chip detector and oil filter then close drains.
Remove cover plates from pads of accessory drives and spray exposed surfaces and gearshaft with engine lubricating oil (PWC03-001). Replace cover plates.
Install plugs, caps and covers to all engine openings to prevent entry of foreign material and moisture accumulation (Ref. Fig. ).
Tag oil filler cap with date of preservation.

figure.title: Location of Shipping Covers and Plugs

key.def: Oil-to-Cooler and Oil Return Shipping Cap
Torquemeter Oil and Dump Valve Drain Shipping Cap
Oil Temperature and Fuel Vent Shipping Plug

n-para.title: Removal of Engine from Stand (Ref. Fig. )

procedure.title: Procedure
procedure.step: The following procedure is for removal of the engine from the overhaul stand after testing and final assembly checks. The instructions refer to the engine mountings installed for testing (Ref. Para. ). Attach sling (PWC32420) or (PWC50066) or (PWC51861-600) to engine lifting points (12 and 13) and take up slack on hoist. Remove cotterpins (21), castellated nuts (20), washers (17, 19) and bolts (16) securing top (small) section of mount ring (10) to engine mount brackets (7) at 2 and 10 o'clock positions on engine. Remove bolts (8) securing top section of mount ring to locking plates (9) on bottom section. Lift off top section and retain with stand. Remove cotter pins (21), nuts (20), washers (17,19) and bolts (16) securing the bottom (large) section of mount ring (10) to engine mounting brackets (7) at the 4 and 8 o'clock position on the engine. After removal retain all nuts, bolts and washers in a plastic bag attached to the stand or insert into appropriate positions in mountings after engine removal. Lift engine clear of stand. Remove bolts (18) securing four mount brackets (7) to gas generator case of engine. Remove brackets and retain with stand.

n-para.title: Installation of Engine in Fiberboard Container

procedure.title: Preparation
procedure.caution: ENSURE OIL HAS BEEN COMPLETELY DRAINED FROM ENGINE.
procedure.step: When an engine is to be installed in a fiberboard container, the following precautions must be taken. Ensure a hoist of sufficient lifting capacity and safety factor is available to lift the following loads. 475 lbs. (215 kg) engine only. 800 lbs. (362 kg) engine loaded in fiberboard container. Ensure engine is positioned correctly, directly beneath hoist. Ensure a clear overhead space of at least eight feet is available, not including distance from top of engine to hoist hook. Install shipping cover (Ref. item 40, Fig. ) over air intake screen. Ensure cradle and skid base are serviceable, and that a new or serviceable fiberboard sleeve and lid are available. Secure ignition cables to engine with pressure-sensitive tape (PWC05-070).

procedure.title: Procedure (Ref. Fig. and )
procedure.caution: DO NOT USE STANDARD COMMERCIAL HARDWARE TO SECURE ENGINE SUPPORT BRACKETS TO ENGINE OR CONTAINER, USE OF HARDWARE OF LOWER STRENGTH THAN SPECIFIED COULD CAUSE SERIOUS ENGINE DAMAGE DURING SHIPPING.
procedure.step: Check that interior of protective envelope is free of dirt, oil water or other contaminants.
Remove engine from engine stand (Ref. Para. ).
Install new protective envelope (4, Fig. ) under engine so gaskets are aligned with lower engine mounting pads on each side of engine and accessory gearbox mounting pad.
Attach engine front mount brackets (7) to lower engine mounting pads on each side of gas generator case with eight bolts (6). Tighten bolts and torque 225 to 250 lb.in.

Attach engine rear mount bracket (10) to mounting pad at 6 o'clock position on accessories gearbox, with three bolts (6). Tighten bolts and torque 50 to 70 lb.in. Fiberboard shipping container cradles (30332) must be replaced with modified cradles (3032) when they are to be used to store or ship PT6A-41 engines (3012).
Lower engine into cradle (8) and secure engine front and rear mount brackets (7) and (10) to clevis on cradle with three lanyard-attached engine mount pins (5).
Secure humidity indicator to protective envelope, in correct position to be visible through fiberboard sleeve window.

Place engine log book, log sheets and other relevant papers to be shipped with engine, in a waterproof envelope and seal with pressure sensitive tape (PWC05-070). Insert envelope in the box secured to skid base and seal box.
Remove sling and hoist from engine.

Tie 12 (eight unit) freshly activated desiccant bags to engine, evenly disposed over engine length, six on each side. Remove desiccant bags from protective polyethylene bag before installation. Do not place desiccant bags on or near the compressor inlet to avoid possible ingestion of desiccant particles by the engine.
Heat seal along top of envelope, using suitable hand sealing iron, leaving one corner open. Evacuate air, fold corner and heat seal.

Place overhauled ignition exciter (Ref. 74-10-00) in protective envelope (11). Insert one four-unit desiccant bag in envelope. Heat seal envelope leaving one corner open, evacuate air from envelope, fold corner and heat seal. Secure exciter and envelope to skid base using four bolts, washers and nuts.
Install fiberboard sleeve (5, Fig. ) with plywood side supports (4) over engine and fit in position on skid base (9).
Fold engine envelope and ensure humidity indicator (12) aligns with window in sleeve. Tape envelope folds with pressure sensitive tape (13) (PWC05-070).
Close flaps of sleeve and seal with pressure sensitive tape (13).
Place cover (1) and plywood cover support (14) on sleeve, fold flaps down and seal at each corner with pressure-sensitive tape (13).
Secure cover horizontally with 3/4 inch commercial steel strap (3), seals and four metal reinforcing corners (2).

Secure cover and sleeve to skid base with four 3/4 inch commercial steel straps (3), seals and sixteen metal reinforcing corners (2). Five seals are required on PT6A-38 containers,10 seals are required on all other engine model containers.

n-para.title: Installation of Engine in Metal Container

procedure.title: Preparation
procedure.step: When an engine is to be installed in a metal container, the following precautions must be taken. Ensure a hoist of sufficient lifting capacity and safety factor is available to lift the following loads. 475 lbs. (215 kg) engine only. 1500 lbs. (680 kg) engine loaded in metal container. Ensure engine is positioned correctly, directly beneath hoist. Ensure a clear overhead space of at least eight feet is available, not including distance from top of engine to hoist hook. With engine mounted in stand (Ref. Para. ) and engine preservation procedure accomplished (Ref. Para. ), fit all shipping covers and plugs (Ref. Fig. ). Install shipping cover (Ref. item 40, Fig ) around engine inlet screen. Install moisture barrier/protective cover over compressor bleed valve exhaust housing on each side of engine. Secure covers with pressure sensitive tape. Ensure that top and bottom halves of metal container interior are clean and dry. Ensure that mating flange of top and bottom halves of metal container are clean and free from damage. Ensure that gasket (7, Fig. ) is serviceable, otherwise replace with new gasket.

procedure.title: Install Engine In Metal Container
procedure.step: Install ignition exciter on its mount pad on cradle structure and secure with four bolts, washers and self-locking nuts. Tighten nuts and torque 32 to 36 lb.in.
CHECK OIL HAS BEEN COMPLETELY DRAINED FROM ENGINE.Attach sling to hoist, with sling lifting eye adjusted for level engine lift.
Secure sling to engine lifting brackets (9 and 10, Fig. ), and support weight of engine on sling.
Remove two bolts (7) and washers (6) on each side of engine securing engine mount brackets (5 and 12) to stand.
Raise engine carefully until clear of stand. Remove stand and unscrew eight bolts (11) securing engine mount brackets (5) and (12) to engine, and remove brackets.
Install engine center-mount shipping covers (6, Fig. ) to engine center upper mount pad on each side of engine, and secure each cover with four bolts.

DO NOT USE STANDARD COMMERCIAL HARDWARE TO SECURE ENGINE SUPPORT BRACKETS TO ENGINE OR CONTAINER. USE OF HARDWARE OF LOWER STRENGTH THAN SPECIFIED COULD CAUSE SERIOUS DAMAGE DURING SHIPPING.Remove two engine front mount brackets (8, Fig. ) from cradle, and secure brackets to engine front lower mount pads on each side of engine using eight bolts (7) and washers. Tighten bolts and torque 225 to 250 lb.in.
Remove engine rear mount bracket (4) from cradle, and secure bracket to engine rear mount pad using three bolts (6) and washers. Tighten bolts and torque 50 to 70 lb.in.
Carefully lower engine onto cradle. Secure engine front mounting brackets (8) to cradle with two lanyard-attached pins (5).
Secure engine rear mount bracket (4) to cradle with lanyard-attached pin (5).

Insert eight bags of desiccant (64 units total) into cage (12), and close opening with lockwire (PWC05-089). Reverse and reuse humidity indicator (if serviceable), otherwise replace (Ref. IPC). Make sure desiccant bags are removed from protective polyethylene containers.
Liberally coat gasket (7, Fig. ) with anti-sticking compound (PWC09-003), and install gasket in position on container base (18) mating flange.
Lift container top cover into position using hoist and sling at lifting points (3). Lower top cover over locating pin (13).
Secure top cover to container base using 40 bolts (6), lockwashers (5) and nuts (4). Tighten and torque bolts 270 to 300 lb.in.
Coat all exposed hardware with preservative compound (PWC15-014).
Install engine log book and relevant shipping documents in rectangular recess in container base and replace cover (20); secure with butterfly nuts (19) and lockwire (PWC05-089).
Stencil engine model, serial number, rubber date and pertinent preservation and inspection dates on the white panel adjacent to humidity indicator.
Check service receptacle cover is secure, lockwired and lead-sealed.

title.xref: Removal/Installation of Engine from Fiberboard Container
Metal Storage and Shipping Container Components
Location of Shipping Covers and Plugs
Metal Storage and Shipping Container, Leading Particulars

n-para.title: General
n-para.para: Figures through , following, should be used as a guide during engine test to trace and rectify any problem that may arise after scheduled or unscheduled overhaul. In some instances, the problem may be resolved in the test cell, otherwise the engine must be returned to the overhaul shop for unscheduled overhaul.

To facilitate troubleshooting, the common engine problems are divided into four categories, each of which contains probable symptoms of defects or malfunction in the system(s) related to that category. Diagnostic and corrective actions required to isolate and rectify the various problems are linked in logic form to each of the symptoms.

Troubleshooting is confined to engine and accessory equipment defects and does not extend to detailed checks on test facility systems and instrumentation, the integrity of which must be verified by regular calibration. Defects in test facility systems, instrumentation and equipment should be diagnosed and rectified by reference to appropriate charts and interface diagrams contained in the Test Facility Planning Manual P/N 3040888.

procedure.title: Engine Problem Categories
procedure.step: Starting Problems (Ref. Figure ).
Operating Problems (Ref. Figure ).
Lubricating System Problems (Ref. Figure ).
Unacceptable Performance Parameters (Ref. Figure ).

general.para: Light overhaul constitutes a service requirement necessary to investigate and rectify a problem or defect for which an engine, sub-assembly or component has been returned to an overhaul facility after unscheduled removal.

Depending on the nature of the problem or defect and the assembly component(s) involved, the scope of light overhaul can vary considerably from normal scheduled overhaul, especially when diagnostic capabilities are required for inspection purposes. Because of this, special procedures covering disassembly, cleaning, inspection, repair or replacement, and assembly, are included in the Light Overhaul section of the various Chapters concerned.
To avoid repetition, normal overhaul procedures which apply (in whole or in part) to light overhaul are cross-referenced in all Chapters dealing with light overhaul.

All parts undergoing light overhaul must be inspected by trained specialists capable of deciding, when no limits are specified, whether such parts are suitable for further service, require repair, or require replacement with new parts.

procedure.title: Special Conditions Necessitating Unscheduled Removal And Return Of Engine Or Power Section For Light Overhaul
procedure.step: Overtorque
Hot Section Inspection
Overtemperature
Overspeed
Sudden Stoppage
Unusual Oil System Conditions
Lightning Strike
Immersion in Water
Dropped Engine
High Oil Consumption (Smoky Starts)
Loss of all power turbine blades (not associated with loss of compressor turbine blades).

Damaged ring gear, first and second-stage sun gears or power turbine shaft coupling. Limits and definitions for overtorque, overtemperature, overspeed, sudden stoppage etc., governing eligibility for unscheduled inspection, are specified in Chapter 72-00-00, Maintenance Manual P/N 3021442.
Contamination by fire extinguishing agent.

subpara.title: General
subpara.para: The following information is intended as a reference guide for assemblies, components and accessories returned to an overhaul facility after unscheduled removal.

procedure.title: Engine Problems and Defects
procedure.step: The problems and defects are diagnosed and the engine is separated into three major sub-assemblies as follows: Power Section (Ref. 72-01-00) Accessory Gearbox (Ref. 72-60-00) Gas Generator Assembly (Ref. 72-30-00)

Each major sub-assembly is further separated into minor assemblies, which are subject to unscheduled overhaul procedures in their appropriate chapter, to resolve and rectify the problem or defect. Refer to Light Overhaul in the relevant chapter of this manual (Ref. Table ) and also the following paragraphs. If borescope equipment is available, visual inspection of hot section components may be carried out using this equipment without disassembly of the engine. Refer to the INTRODUCTION section of this manual for details of borescope inspection.

table.title: Light Overhaul Reference for Unscheduled Removal - Engine

row.entry: Loss of all Power Turbine Blades (not associated with the loss of compressor turbine blades)
Damaged Ring Gear, First and Second-stage Sun Gears or Power Turbine Shaft Coupling

procedure.title: Categories
procedure.step: Engines subjected to overtemperature during starting conditions or all conditions except starting or inadvertent cut-off and relight during taxi condition are classified into separate categories for light overhaul of the power section and gas generator assembly: When overtemperature conditions fall within Area C for all conditions except starting (Ref. Fig. ) or starting conditions only (Ref. Fig. ) or inadvertent cut-off and relight during taxi (Ref. Fig. ), do overtemperature inspection of power section (Ref. 72-01-00, LIGHT OVERHAUL) and gas generator assembly (Ref. 72-30-00, LIGHT OVERHAUL). When overtemperature conditions fall within Area B for inadvertent cut-off and relight during taxi, do stretch check and fluorescent penetrant inspection of the compressor turbine disk and blade assembly. This inspection must be accompanied with metallurgical analysis (cut-up) of two blades.

figure.title: Overtemperature Limits - All Conditions Except Starting
Inadvertent Cut-off and Relight During Taxi

procedure.title: Inspect Engine Dropped
procedure.step: Remove engine from container (Ref. Storage).
Crack check suspected areas in accordance with SPOP 70.
Inspect engine and accessory mount pads and all cast housings for cracks.
Inspect exhaust duct and gas generator case for buckling, distortion and cracks.
Inspect tubing, sense lines, brackets and sheet metal parts for distortion.
Check for security of attachment and integrity of mounting flanges of all accessories.
Separate power section from gas generator assembly (Ref. Disassembly) and conduct inspection of these assemblies (Ref. 72-01-00 and 72-30-00, LIGHT OVERHAUL).

procedure.title: General
procedure.step: This information should be used as a guide for metallic contamination identification and not as a specification of engine serviceability. Qualified personnel should carefully analyze the unusual oil conditions prevailing on the engine and determine the extent of disassembly necessary to correct the problem in the appropriate light overhaul sections of each affected chapter.
When metal contaminants are evident, consideration must be given to particle/flake size, shape and engine operating history.
A particle is a piece of metal of finite thickness, large enough in area to become entrapped on the main oil filter surface.
A flake is a metal chip having immeasurable thickness, but large enough to become entrapped on the main oil filter surface.
When a fire extinguisher has been used on the engine, consideration must be given to the possibility of the extinguishing agent entering the oil system and contaminating the oil.

procedure.title: Examples of Possible Contamination
procedure.step: Small flakes of non-ferrous metal normally originate from plain bearings or bushings of Babbitt, tin, bronze or silver.
Small flakes of ferrous metal normally originate from spalled anti-friction bearings, gear teeth or from fretting.
Slivers of steel normally originate from interference between steel parts or from heavy scoring.
Fuzz or powdered material is cast iron and originates from propeller shaft oil transfer sleeve.

procedure.title: Unusual Oil Conditions (Part A)
procedure.step: Loss of oil and/or fluctuating engine or torquemeter oil pressure.
Pressure dropped below nominal value but remained above 60 psi. No metal particles found in main oil filter or chip detector.
Less than 40 non-magnetic particles found in the main oil filter.
Fire extinguishing agent contamination of the oil and oil system.

procedure.title: Unusual Oil Conditions (Part B)
procedure.step: Loss of oil and/or fluctuating engine or torquemeter oil pressure.
Pressure dropped below 60 psi. Metal particles found in main oil filter or chip detector.
Any magnetic particles or more than 40 non-magnetic particles, found in main oil filter.
Engine rejected for propeller shaft seizure.
Fire extinguishing agent contamination of the oil and oil system.

procedure.title: Rectify Part A (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: When source of problem has been determined, separate engine into the following sub-assemblies: Power section (Ref. 72-10-00). Gas generator assembly (Ref. 72-30-00). Accessory gearbox (Ref. 72-60-00). Refer to Disassembly in this chapter to separate engine into sub-assemblies.
Disassemble, clean, inspect and repair the suspect major sub-assemblies and accessory components (Ref. Tables and ).
Disassemble and pressure flush propeller reduction gearbox, accessory gearbox and oil tank. Oil tank may be flushed in-situ.
Inspect pressure and scavenge pumps on accessory gearbox (Ref. 72-60-00, LIGHT OVERHAUL).
Reverse flush oil-to-fuel heater (Ref. 73-10-01).
Remove and clean oil filter, housing and check valve (Ref. 79-20-02).
Remove and clean oil pressure relief valve or regulator valve (Ref. 72-60-00).
Reassemble power section, gas generator assembly and accessory gearbox.
Reassemble engine and install external and accessory components (Ref. Assembly).
Test engine (Ref. Testing).

procedure.title: Rectify Condition (Part B)
procedure.step: Remove the following externals and accessories (Ref. Disassembly). Propeller governor (Ref. 61-20-00). Oil-to-fuel heater (Ref. 73-10-01). Pressure oil tubes (Ref. 79-20-01). No. 2 bearing scavenge oil tube (Ref. 79-20-01). External scavenge oil tubes (Ref. 79-20-01). Oil filter, housing and check valve (Ref. 79-20-02). Oil pressure regulating or relief valve (Ref. 72-60-00). Thermostatic bypass/check and diverter valve (if fitted) (Ref. 79-20-03). Magnetic chip detector (Ref. 72-10-00).
Conduct light overhaul for unusual oil conditions on each external/accessory in appropriate chapter number listed.
Separate engine into the following sub-assemblies: Power section (Ref. 72-01-00). Gas generator assembly (Ref. 72-30-00). Accessory gearbox (Ref. 72-60-00).
Separate power section into the following sub-assemblies: Propeller reduction gearbox (Ref. 72-00-00). Power turbine installation (Ref. 72-50-04).

Separate gas generator assembly into the following sub-assemblies: Compressor inlet case (Ref. 72-20-00). Compressor rotor (Ref. 72-30-05). Gas generator case (Ref. 72-30-04). Although removal of No. 1 and No. 2 bearings from the compressor rotor is necessary, disassembly of compressor rotor is not required.

Separate accessory gearbox into the following sub-assemblies: Accessory gearbox. Overhaul (Ref. 72-60-00). Oil filter, housing and check valve. Overhaul (Ref. 79-20-02). Oil pressure relief or regulating valve. Overhaul (Ref. 72-60-00).
Conduct light overhaul procedures on sub-assemblies referenced in steps , and preceding.

subpara.para: If a power section is returned to an overhaul facility for unscheduled overhaul, refer to 72-01-00, LIGHT OVERHAUL.

If any of the following engine components (Ref. Table ) are returned to an overhaul facility after unscheduled overhaul, refer to 72-30-00, LIGHT OVERHAUL.
Light Overhaul Reference for Unscheduled Removal - Engine Components
COMPONENTCHAPTER
Compressor Turbine (Blade Shift) 72-50-02
Combustion Chamber Exit Duct (Small) 72-50-01
Combustion Chamber Exit Duct (Large) 72-50-01
Combustion Chamber Liner 72-40-01

For any accessory returned to an overhaul facility after unscheduled removal, refer to LIGHT OVERHAUL in the relevant chapter of this manual. A comprehensive list of accessory part numbers versus Vendor- supplied accessory manuals is provided in the P&WC Illustrated Parts Catalog.
subpara.note: Where light overhaul is not specified, refer to normal scheduled overhaul instructions in the relevant Accessories Overhaul Manual.

subpara.para: External components removed at engine disassembly, or accessory related parts received following unscheduled removal, may be subjected to Light Overhaul procedures, to resolve a problem or defect, for which an engine has been returned to an overhaul facility.

Refer to LIGHT OVERHAUL in the relevant chapter of this manual (Ref. Table ).

general.para: Personnel disassembling the power section should refer to the Introduction of this manual to familiarize themselves with general overhaul procedures (Ref. INTRODUCTION, How to Use this Manual).
Refer to general disassembly procedures (Ref. Chap. 72-00-00, DISASSEMBLY) for removal of power section from gas generator assembly.
Secure the power section in stand (Ref. Chap. 72-00-00, DISASSEMBLY). Disassemble the power section into subassemblies for overhaul as described in the appropriate Chapter/Section/Unit.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

procedure.title: Removal of T5 Lead-Out Harness and Busbar Assembly (3197) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove lead-out harness and busbar: Position power section vertically in stand (PWC34300) or (PWC51140) or (PWC70907) with power turbines facing upward. Disconnect chromel and alumel terminals using holding fixture (PWC32125): Position fixture (17) over junction box (5) with slotted finger (16) over thermocouple terminal capscrew (6). Clamp fixture (17) to power turbine stator housing (1) with knurled screws (14). Secure junction box (5) with position adjusting knob (18) and T-screw (15). Remove
capscrew (6, pt6a38-772001-002-0030 1 3322) or bolt (20, pt6a38-772001-002-0030 1 3322 and 3334) from chromel terminal. Loosen T-screw (15), position adjusting knob (18) and knurled screws (14), reposition holding fixture (17) over terminal capscrew (7, 3322) or bolt (21, 3322 and 3334) (Ref. steps to preceding) and remove
capscrew (7) pt6a38-772001-002-0020 1 or bolt (21) pt6a38-772001-002-0020 1 from alumel terminal. Remove terminals and reinstall capscrews or bolts in junction box.
Removal of T5 Lead-out Harness and Busbar Assembly (3197)
1.Power Turbine Stator Housing 2.Exhaust Duct3.Bolt4.Washer5. Junction Box6.Capscrew, Chromel (CR) Terminal (3322)7.Capscrew, Alumel (AL) Terminal (3322)8.T5 Lead-out Harness9.Bolt10.Gasket11. Washer12.Busbar13. Thermocouple Coupling14.Knurled Screw15.T-screw16. Slotted Finger17.Holding Fixture 18.Position Adjusting Knob19. Thermocouple Probe20.Bolt, Chromel (CR) Terminal (3322, 3334) 21.Bolt, Alumel (AL) Terminal (3322, 3334) Remove two bolts (9) pt6a38-772001-002-0170 2 , detach harness (8) pt6a38-772001-002-0010 1 at clips and remove from stator housing (1) and exhaust duct (2). USE CARE NOT TO TWIST OR OTHERWISE DAMAGE BUSBAR WHEN UNSCREWING COUPLINGS.Unscrew thermocouple couplings (13) using wrench (PWC30114-08) and a standard 3/8-inch square drive socket handle. DO NOT FLEX BUSBAR ANY MORE THAN NECESSARY TO DISENGAGE PROBES OTHERWISE DAMAGE TO BUSBAR INSULATION MAY RESULT.Remove three bolts (3) pt6a38-772001-001-0020 3 and washers (4) pt6a38-772001-001-0030 3 . Carefully withdraw probes (19) pt6a38-772001-001-0090 10 from stator housing (1) (remove end probes first), and remove busbar assembly (12) pt6a38-772001-001-0010 1 . Overhaul busbar assembly and T5 lead-out harness (Ref. 77-20-01).

procedure.title: Removal of T5 Immersion Thermocouples, Bus-Bars and Wiring Harness (3197), and Blanking Thermocouples (3241) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove self-locking nuts (10) pt6a38-772001-002-0036 1 and (13) pt6a38-772001-002-0038 1 and bolts
(11) pt6a38-772001-002-0035 1 and (12) pt6a38-772001-002-0037 1 which secure wiring harness (3) to bus-bars (15) and (16).
Remove lacing wire securing harness (3) to clips on power turbine stator housing (1).
Remove bolts (6) pt6a38-772001-002-0170 2 securing harness flange (5) to exhaust duct conduit flange.
Remove harness (3) pt6a38-772001-002-0010 1 through conduit on exhaust duct.
Remove gasket (7) pt6a38-772001-002-0180 1 from flange (5) and discard.
Remove bolts (17) pt6a38-772001-001-0060 10 and washers pt6a38-772001-001-0065 10 (3253) from positive bus-bar (15); remove bus-bar pt6a38-772001-001-0050 1 .
Remove bolts (18) pt6a38-772001-001-0080 10 and washers pt6a38-772001-001-0085 10 (3253) from negative bus-bar (16); remove bus-bar pt6a38-772001-001-0070 1 .

For 3241 Engines: Loosen bolt/couplings (20) using wrench (PWC30114-05), and remove immersion thermocouples (19) pt6a38-772001-001-0090 10 from the ten thermocouple locations in the stator housing (1). Discard copper washers (22) pt6a38-772001-001-0100 AR .

For 3241 Engines: Loosen bolt/couplings (20) using wrench (PWC30114-05), and remove blanking thermocouples (23) pt6a38-772001-001-0095 2 from the two lower thermocouple locations in the stator housing (1), and immersion thermocouples (19) pt6a38-772001-001-0090 8 from the remaining eight thermocouple locations in the stator housing. Discard copper washers (22) pt6a38-772001-001-0100 AR .
Overhaul bus-bar assembly, wiring harness assembly and thermocouples (Ref. 77-20-01).

figure.title: Removal of T5 Thermocouples, Bus Bars and Wiring Harness (3197), and Blanking Thermocouples (3241)

procedure.title: Removal of Power Turbine Stator Housing and Stator Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Disassemble and remove stator assembly from stator housing: Remove twelve bolts (5) pt6a38-725003-001-0020 12 , and withdraw power turbine stator housing assembly (4) pt6a38-725003-001-0010 1 from exhaust duct (1) using puller (PWC32111). For 3337 Engines and PT6A-42A: Remove and discard collapsed seal ring (6) pt6a38-725005-001-0060 1 . Remove stator assembly (2) pt6a38-725003-001-0070 1 and vane ring retaining ring (3) pt6a38-725003-001-0225 1 (3092).

procedure.title: Removal of Power Turbines, Second-Stage Vane Ring and Shroud (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove power turbines, second-stage vane ring and shroud: Unstake slotted washer (6). Remove power turbines retaining nut (5) pt6a38-725004-002-0290 pt6a38-725004-003-0290 1 and slotted washer (6) pt6a38-725004-002-0300 pt6a38-725004-003-0300 1 from shaft with socket (PWC34259 or (PWC50372) or PWC50442), wrench (PWC31050), bar (PWC34258) and adapter (PWC31515). Discard nut (3101). For instructions on use of power torque wrench, refer to INTRODUCTION. If retaining nut (5) has seized, use the following alternate method: Use of oil is recommended during drilling operation. Drills are specially prepared for this operation; do not resharpen. Use fixture (PWC32136) to drill two holes in power turbine retaining nut (5) to the depth limited by stop on drill. Remove power turbines retaining nut (5) and slotted washer (6) from shaft with socket (PWC32137), wrench (PWC31050), bar (PWC34258) and adapter (PWC31515). Discard nut (3101). Remove
first-stage power turbine (7) pt6a38-725004-002-0220 pt6a38-725004-003-0220 1 from shaft with puller (PWC32123) or (PWC50588), cylinder (PWC89837), pump (PWC32507) and pad (PWC50042). Place turbine carefully in a suitable protective container. If both disks withdraw together, separate: Close spring-loaded claws of adapter (PWC32121) or (PWC50589), insert into bore of second-stage disk, and release. Insert solid end of pusher (PWC32120) into first-stage disk and locate end in bore of adapter. Install puller (PWC32123) or (PWC50588) on first-stage disk, locate centerscrew pad in end of pusher, and turn centerscrew until disks separate. Remove power turbine disks from the shaft using alternate method and tooling as follows: Connect first-stage disk puller (PWC50588) to disk flange. Install the power turbine shaft pad (PWC51752) into back of the puller. Connect hydraulic cylinder adapter (PWC71392) to the puller. Thread the hydraulic cylinder (PWC89837) into the adapter. Connect hydraulic pump (PWC32507) to the cylinder and apply pressure to remove the disk. If second stage power turbine is still on the shaft, remove turbine using above steps, but use puller (PWC50763) and pad (PWC50766). If you remove both turbine disks together, then separate them on bench using alternate method and tooling as follows: Connect first-stage disk puller (PWC50588) to disk flange. Install the body of the puller (PWC50589) through the puller and into the disk assembly. From the opposite end of the disk assembly, thread the guide (PWC50589) into the body of the puller (PWC50589). Connect hydraulic cylinder adapter (PWC71392) to the puller. Thread the hydraulic cylinder (PWC89837) into the adapter. Connect the hydraulic pump (PWC32507) to the cylinder and apply pressure to separate the disks. Remove all tools. Remove
second-stage vane ring assembly (8) pt6a38-725004-004-0010 1 . Removal of Power Turbine Stator Housing and Stator Assembly
1. Exhaust Duct2. Stator3. Vane Ring Retaining Ring (3092)4.Stator Housing 5.Bolt6.Sealing Ring (3337 and PT6A-42A)
Removal of Power Turbines, Second-Stage Vane Ring and Shroud
1.No. 3 Bearing Cover2. Retaining Ring3.Second-stage Power Turbine4.Interstage Rotor Air Seal 5.Plain Nut6.Slotted Washer7.First-stage Power Turbine 8.Second-stage Vane Ring9. Power Turbine Shroud To remove interstage rotor air seal (4) pt6a38-725004-002-0280 pt6a38-725004-003-0280 1 from second-stage disk, insert split collet of puller (PWC32119) into bore of seal and turn centerscrew inwards against disk. If second-stage turbine (3) pt6a38-725004-002-0190 pt6a38-725004-003-0190 1 is still on shaft, remove it with puller (PWC32320) or (PWC50763). Place turbine carefully into a suitable protective container. If power turbine rotor air seal is withdrawn from shaft coupling during turbine removal, remove it from turbine disk and retain with shaft housing assembly. Remove power turbine shroud (9) pt6a38-725003-001-230 1 . Remove retaining ring (2) pt6a38-725004-001-0160 pt6a38-725004-001a-0160 1 , and withdraw No. 3 bearing cover assembly (1) pt6a38-725004-001-0170 pt6a38-725004-001a-0170 1 (3172 and 3172 on PT6A-42 engines). Overhaul power turbine stator housing, stator and shroud (Ref. 72-50-03), and power turbine installation and second-stage vane ring assembly (Ref. 72-50-04).

procedure.title: Removal of Reduction Gearbox Front Housing Assembly (Ref. Fig. )

figure.title: Removal of Reduction Gearbox Front Housing Assembly

procedure.step:
Remove reduction gearbox front housing assembly as follows: Position power section vertically in stand with reduction gearbox up. Remove
self-locking nuts (1) pt6a38-721000-001-0050 36 , washers (2) pt6a38-721000-001-0040 36 , bolts (4) pt6a38-721000-001-0020 7 and
(5) pt6a38-721000-001-0010 29 , lifting bracket (3) pt6a38-721000-001-0030 1 and on 3323 engines, bracket (8). Separate reduction gearbox front housing from rear housing, using four jackscrews (PWC42034) or (PWC32396-400) in threaded holes in flange A. Attach lifting adapter (PWC50940) to propeller shaft flange. Use a suitable hoist, lift front-half of reduction gearbox front housing assembly and install it on plate (PWC32079). Remove jackscrews and lifting eye. Overhaul reduction gearbox front housing assembly (Ref. 72-10-00).

procedure.title: Removal of Reduction Gearbox Rear Housing and Power Turbine Shaft Assembly (Ref. Fig.)
procedure.step:
Remove gearbox rear housing assembly and power turbine shaft assembly from exhaust duct as follows: Lift reduction gearbox rear housing (1), with power turbine shaft housing (8) attached, from exhaust duct (11). Remove three transfer tubes (14) pt6a38-721000-002-0170 3 and sleeve strainer (15) pt6a38-721000-002-0190 1 , and place assembly on bench, flange A down. Remove
self-locking nuts (7) pt6a38-725004-001-0020 pt6a38-725004-001a-0020 12 , and remove shaft housing assembly (8) pt6a38-725004-001-0010 1 , with first-stage reduction sun gear set attached, from gearbox rear housing (1). Overhaul rear-half reduction gearbox assembly (Ref. 72-01-00), and power turbine shaft housing assembly (Ref. 72-50-04).

procedure.title: Removal of Thermal Insulation Blanket and Exhaust Duct (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Remove insulation blanket from exhaust duct and exhaust duct from stand as follows: Withdraw thermal insulation blanket (12) pt6a38-725005-001-0040 from exhaust duct (11). Remove exhaust duct pt6a38-725005-001-0010 1 from stand. Overhaul thermal insulation blanket and exhaust duct (Ref. 72-50-05). general.para: Personnel assembling the power section should refer to the Introduction section of this manual to familiarize themselves with general overhaul procedures (Ref. INTRODUCTION, How to Use this Manual).

This chapter describes the assembly and installation of each overhauled sub-assembly, in a logical sequence, until the power section build is complete, and ready for installation on engine at Final Assembly (Ref. 72-00-00, FINAL ASSEMBLY).

A table of fits and clearances contained in this chapter (Ref. Table 601) is provided for reference during assembly and installation of power section subassemblies, when dimensional and clearance checks may be required between mating parts, and in related chapters where fits and clearances tables deal specifically with one of the two mating components in question.

consumables.para: The consumable materials listed below are used in the following procedures.

special-tools.para: The special tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

fixtures-and-equipment.para: The fixtures, equipment and supplier tools listed below are used in the following procedures.

row.entry: Test Set, Turbine Temperature Indicating (or equivalent)

procedure.title: Installation of the Power Turbine Shaft Housing (Ref. Fig.)
procedure.step:
Place overhauled reduction gearbox rear housing (Ref. 72-01-00) on bench, flange A downward, and install assembled shaft housing (Ref. 72-50-04) as follows: Install preformed packing (5) pt6a38-725004-001-0030 1 in groove on gearbox rear housing (1) pt6a38-721000-002-0200 pt6a38-721000-006-0001 1, 1 . Installation of Reduction Gearbox Rear Housing and Power Turbine Shaft Housing
1.Reduction Gearbox Rear Housing 2.Preformed Packing3. Transfer Tube4.Oil Jet Strainer 5.Preformed Packing6. Pressure Oil Tube (Nos. 3 and 4 Bearings)7. Self-locking Nut8.Power Turbine Shaft Housing Assembly9.Scavenge Oil Tube (Nos. 3 and 4 Bearings)10.Preformed Packing11.Exhaust Duct12.Thermal Insulation Blanket13. Preformed Packing14.Transfer Tube 15.Sleeve Strainer Remove blanking cap from end of pressure oil tube (6) pt6a38-725004-001-0080 1 in power turbine shaft housing assembly pt6a38-725004-001-0010 1 , and check that oil jet strainer (4) pt6a38-725004-001-0060 1 is installed. Install two preformed packings (2) pt6a38-725004-001-0050 2 on transfer tube (3) pt6a38-725004-001-0040 1 , and install transfer tube in end of pressure oil tube (6). Install preformed packing (10) pt6a38-725004-001-0110 1 over end of scavenge oil tube (9) pt6a38-725004-001-0100 1 . Check that planet gear marked 'X' is aligned with ring gear tooth marked 'X', ensuring that the two planet gear teeth with the word 'UP' straddle the 'X' mark on ring gear (Ref. Fig., View A). Planet gears 'Y' and 'Z' must be aligned in a similar manner with ring gear marks. Lower power turbine shaft housing assembly (8) onto rear-half reduction gearbox assembly (1). Align transfer tubes, dowel pin and studs with corresponding holes, meshing sun gear with planet gears, and press into position. Secure assemblies together with 12 self-locking nuts (7) pt6a38-725004-001-0020 12 . Torque nuts 150 to 170 lb.in., evenly.

procedure.title: Installation of the Insulation Blanket and the Reduction Gearbox Rear Housing (Ref. Fig )
procedure.step: Install shaft housing and gearbox rear housing assembly, and thermal insulation blanket in exhaust duct as follows: Install exhaust duct (11) pt6a38-725005-001-0010 1 in stand (PWC34300) or (PWC51140) or (PWC70907) and attach to mount ring (PWC30269). Ensure exhaust duct is applicable 3172 or 3172 configuration. Rotate mount ring to bring exhaust duct flange A uppermost. Insert thermal insulation blanket (12) pt6a38-725005-001-0040 1 into exhaust duct. Lower gearbox rear housing and shaft housing assembly into exhaust duct, aligning bolt holes in flanges.

procedure.title: Installation of Reduction Gearbox Front Housing Assembly (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install gearbox front housing assembly on rear housing and exhaust duct as follows: Check preformed packings pt6a38-721000-002-0180 6 (13, Ref. Fig. ) are installed on three transfer tubes (14) pt6a38-721000-002-0170 3 and inserted in ports in rear housing, and
strainer (15) pt6a38-721000-002-0190 1 is located in front case. Attach lifting adapter (6) (PWC50940) to propeller shaft flange. Hoist gearbox front housing assembly and install preformed packing (7) pt6a38-721000-002-0160 1 . Carefully lower gearbox front housing assembly onto gearbox rear housing and exhaust duct. Align transfer tubes with corresponding oil ports, and locate dowel in dowel hole. Turn propeller shaft to facilitate gear meshing during installation. Remove lifting eye (6) from propeller shaft Installation of Reduction Gearbox Front Housing Assembly
1.Self-locking Nut 2. Washer3.Engine Lifting and Accessory Mounting Bracket4.Bolt (Long) 5.Bolt (Short)6.Lifting Adapter7.Preformed Packing 8.Bracket (3323)
WHEN SECURING (3097) GEARBOX FRONT HOUSING TO EXHAUST DUCT, ENSURE THAT BOLTS ARE LONGER THAN THOSE USED FOR 3097.Secure gearbox and exhaust flanges with bolts (5) pt6a38-721000-001-0010 29 , plain washers (2) pt6a38-721000-001-0040 29 and self-locking nuts (1) pt6a38-721000-001-0050 29 . Check bolt heads are on exhaust flange side (facing rear of engine). Torque nuts 36 to 40 lb. in. Install lifting and accessory mounting bracket (3) pt6a38-721000-001-0030 1 to exhaust flange with seven bolts (4) pt6a38-721000-001-0020 7 , plain washers (2) pt6a38-721000-001-0040 7 and self-locking nuts (1) pt6a38-721000-001-0050 7 . Check bolt heads are on exhaust flange side (facing rear of engine). Torque nuts 36 to 40 lb.in. For 3323 front housings: Install bracket (8) to exhaust flange with
bolt (5) pt6a38-721000-001-0010 1 , plain washer (2) pt6a38-721000-001-0040 1 and self-locking nut (1) pt6a38-721000-001-0050 1 . Check bolt head is on exhaust flange side (facing rear of engine). Torque nuts 36 to 40 lb.in.

procedure.title: Determine Class of Bearing Cover (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Measure and record dimension 'A' on second-stage turbine disk.
With power section in vertical position and supported on propeller shaft flange (to load No. 4 bearing), measure and record dimension 'B'.
Determine cover class from following formula:
Cover class (Dim C ± 0.010 in) = Dim 'A' - Dim B - 0.100 in.

figure.title: Determination of No. 3 Bearing Cover Class

procedure.title: Installation of Rotor Air Seal, No. 3 Bearing Cover and Power Turbine Shroud (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install turbines, vane ring and shroud as follows: Heat interstage rotor air seal (6) pt6a38-725004-002-0280 1 to 121°C (250°F) in a temperature-controlled oven. Support second-stage disk (5) pt6a38-725004-002-0220 1 on a flat block. Place interstage rotor air seal on disk so that 'X' mark aligns with large lug, and install seal using drift (PWC32088). Turn power section to vertical position in stand, with reduction gearbox downward. Install
No. 3 bearing cover (3) pt6a38-725004-001-0170 1 as follows: For 3172/PT6A-42 Engines, and 3194 and 3194 Engines: Select bearing cover that is compatible with turbine exhaust duct assembly, and install over end of turbine shaft housing. Secure cover with retaining ring (4) pt6a38-725004-001-0160 1 . For 3257 Engines: Select class of bearing cover required (Ref. para. ) to obtain specified clearance between cover and second-stage power turbine disk (REF. NO 1134, Fits and Clearances), and install cover over end of turbine shaft housing. Secure cover with retaining ring (4) Install power turbine shroud (2) pt6a38-725003-001-0230 1 in exhaust duct (1) pt6a38-725005-001-0010 1 . Ensure shroud flange is in full contact with exhaust duct. Ensure shroud is applicable 3172 or 3172 configuration. BEFORE INSTALLING SECOND-STAGE POWER TURBINE, ENSURE THAT ROTOR AIR SEAL IS PROPERLY INSTALLED ON SHAFT COUPLING.Lightly lubricate snap diameters of second-stage power turbine (5) with a film of engine oil (PWC03-001), and install turbine on shaft. Push hub firmly into shaft coupling, by hand.

figure.title: Installation of Rotor Air Seal, No. 3 Bearing Cover and Power Turbine Shroud

procedure.title: Installation of Second-stage Vane Ring (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install second-stage vane ring assembly (1) pt6a38-725004-001-0010 on shroud. Vane ring (3175) may be replaced with a modified vane ring (3175) incorporating three parallel slots in the inner rim of inner ring to relieve thermal stress.

Lightly lubricate snap diameter of first-stage power turbine (2) pt6a38-725004-003-0220 1 , and install against second-stage turbine, aligning large lug with corresponding slot. Check 'X' marks on disk hub and end of shaft are aligned.
With pusher (PWC32089) or power turbine drift (PWC50767) and rod assembly (PWC71410), push power turbines fully into shaft coupling. Remove pusher or power turbine drift and rod assembly.

Install slotted washer (3) and nut (4) as follows: Install slotted washer pt6a38-725004-003-0300 1 on shaft, with 'X' mark aligned with 'X' mark on power turbine shaft. Screw nut pt6a38-725004-003-0290 1 (3101) on shaft with socket (PWC34259 or (PWC50372) or PWC50442). Leave socket engaged with nut. Nut (3101) is silver plated. Nut (3101) is a similar but wider nut treated with dry film lubricant. Engage adapter (PWC34258) with socket and using power wrench and bar (Ref. items 12 and 19), torque nut (4) to 2400 lb.in. Slacken off nut. Refer to INTRODUCTION of this manual for operation of power wrench. Torque nut (4) to 300 lb.in., then increase torque until nut turns 50 + 2/-0 degrees. Record final torque then slacken off nut. Do not exceed a final torque of 3000 lb.in. Retorque nut (4) to 300 lb.in., then increase torque until nut turns 50 + 2/-0 degrees, as before. Record final torque. If second recorded torque exceeds first recorded torque, slacken nut and repeat torquing procedures until final torque is less than, but within 10% of, previously recorded torque. For PT6A-38/42/42A Engines: Check alignment marks on slotted washer and shaft are aligned. Crimp washer into nut scallops at two positions, 180 degrees apart, with staking tool (PWC51777). For PT6A-41 Engines: Check alignment marks on slotted washer and shaft are aligned. Crimp washer into nut scallops at two positions, 180 degrees apart, with crimper (PWC32093) or (PWC32193).

key.def: Second-stage Vane Ring (3175) Second-stage Vane Ring (3175)

procedure.title: First-stage Stator and Stator Housing (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step: Install stator and stator housing as follows: Ensure vane ring classification is within correct limits (REF. NO. 987, Fits and Clearances), and that stator housing is applicable 3712 or 3172 configuration. Install (snap-on fit) vane ring retaining ring (2) pt6a38-725003-001-0225 1 (3092) on stator (1) pt6a38-725003-001-0070 1 . Place stator assembly carefully over first-stage turbine. Locate flange concentrically with second-stage vane ring, and align lugs. With stator assembly held in firm contact with second-stage vane ring, check joint all round with a 0.001 inch feeler. If feeler enters at any point, rectify joint faces by lapping (Ref. REPAIR, 72-50-03 and 72-50-04). For 3337 and PT6A-42A Engines: Install ring seal (3) pt6a38-725003-001-0240 1 . Install stator housing assembly (4) pt6a38-725003-001-0010 1 in position against exhaust duct flange so that offset holes in both flanges align, and internal slots engage with lugs on second-stage vane ring and stator. Secure flanges together with twelve bolts (5) pt6a38-725003-001-0010 12 . Torque bolts 32 to 36 lb.in.

figure.title: Installation of First-stage Stator and Stator Housing

procedure.title: T5 Thermocouple Busbar and Lead-out Harness (3197) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.step:
Install T5 Thermocouple busbar and lead out harness as follows: DO NOT FLEX BUSBAR MORE THAN NECESSARY TO INSERT PROBES OR DAMAGE TO BUSBAR INSULATION MAY RESULT.Place thermocouple busbar assembly (12) pt6a38-772001-001-0010 1 in position on stator housing (1) pt6a38-725003-001-0010 1 so that brackets align with housing lugs. Install
flat washer (11) pt6a38-772001-001-0040 1 on each
thermocouple probe (19) pt6a38-772001-001-0090 10 , and insert all probes into stator housing bosses. Check that washers are properly seated When fully inserted, probes project through slots in first-stage stator vane ring. Starting with lower right-hand probe (looking toward front of engine), and working progressively counterclockwise, torque thermocouple couplings (13) 40 to 50 lb.in., using wrench (PWC30114-08) and 3/8 inch square drive socket handle. When tightening ensure thermocouple and busbar do not turn with coupling. Secure busbar mounting brackets to rear flange of stator housing with bolts (3) pt6a38-772001-001-0020 3 and washers (4) pt6a38-772001-001-0030 3 . Torque bolts 22 to 24 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089A). Apply a thin film of jointing compound (PWC09-005) to both sides of gasket (10) pt6a38-772001-002-0180 1 , and place gasket in position on flange of
exhaust duct (2) pt6a38-725005-001-0010 1 conduit. Thread T5 lead-out harness (8) pt6a38-772001-002-0010 1 through conduit, and secure elbow flange to duct with two bolts (9) pt6a38-772001-002-0170 2 . Torque bolts 24 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089A). Wipe off excess jointing compound. Using No. 400 grit abrasive cloth (PWC05-013), carefully clean contact surfaces of terminal lugs and terminal posts before connecting. USE CARE WHEN TIGHTENING TERMINAL CAPSCREWS/BOLTS, AS INSULATION MATERIAL BETWEEN TERMINALS AND BOX IS FRAGILE.Connect alumel and chromel terminals using holding fixture (PWC32125). Position holding fixture (17) over junction box (5) with slotted finger (16) over alumel terminal post (larger hole). Clamp fixture (17) to power turbine stator housing (1) with knurled screws (14). Secure junction box (5) with position adjusting knob (18) and T-screw (15). For 3322 Engines: Connect terminal lug with larger hole to alumel (AL) terminal with capscrew (7). Torque capscrew (7) 9 to 12 lb.in. For 3322 and 3334 Engines: Connect terminal lug with larger hole to alumel (AL) terminal with bolt (21). Torque bolt 8 to 10 lb.in. Loosen T-screw (15), position adjusting knob (18) and knurled screws (14), then reposition fixture (17) over chromel terminal post (Ref. steps and preceding). For 3322 Engines: Connect terminal lug with smaller hole to chromel (CR) terminal with capscrew (6) pt6a38-772001-002-0030 1 . Torque capscrew (6) 9 to 12 lb.in. For 3322 and 3334 Engines: Connect terminal lug with smaller hole to chromel (CR) terminal with bolt (20) pt6a38-772001-002-0030 1 . Torque bolt 8 to 12 lb.in. Lock each capscrew (6) and (7) pt6a38-772001-002-0020 1 or bolt (20) and (21) pt6a38-772001-002-0020 1 separately to its associated terminal with lockwire (PWC05-089A). Install wiring harness sleeve in three clips on power turbine stator housing, and secure with wire lacing (PWC05-089A).

figure.title: Installation of T5 Leadout Harness and Thermocouple Busbar (3197)

procedure.title: Install T5 Immersion Thermocouples, Bus-Bars and Wiring Harness (3197), and Blanking Thermocouples (3241) (Ref. Fig. )
procedure.note: All contact surfaces must be cleaned with No. 400 grit abrasive cloth (PWC05-013) prior to assembly.
procedure.step: Apply antiseize compound (PWC06-023) on the T5 probes threads.
Install new copper washer (22) pt6a38-772001-001-0100 AR on each immersion thermocouple (19) pt6a38-772001-001-0090 10 , and on blanking thermocouples (23) pt6a38-772001-001-0095 2 where applicable.

MAKE SURE BOLT/COUPLING (20) IS FREE TO ROTATE ON COLLAR (21) OF THERMOCOUPLE.Install thermocouples: For 3241 Engines: Insert immersion
thermocouples (19) pt6a38-772001-001-0090 10 , complete with washers (22) pt6a38-772001-001-0100 AR , into thread inserts at the ten thermocouple locations in power turbine stator housing (1) pt6a38-725003-001-0010 1 . For 3241 Engines: Insert blanking thermocouples (23) pt6a38-772001-001-0095 2 , complete with washers (22) pt6a38-772001-001-0100 AR , into thread inserts at the two lower thermocouple locations in
stator housing (1) pt6a38-725003-001-0010 1 , and immersion thermocouples (19) pt6a38-772001-001-0090 10 complete with washers (22) pt6a38-772001-001-0100 AR into thread inserts at remaining eight thermocouple locations in stator housing. Make sure larger hole (marked AL) in each thermocouple is facing toward front of engine. Handtighten bolt/coupling (20). Align each thermocouple perpendicular to housing rear flange and torque bolt/coupling (20) (REF. NO. 1079, Fits and Clearances) using wrench (PWC30114-05). Maintain minimum gap between underside of thermocouple cross-piece and stator housing (1) (Ref. Section A-A, Ref. Fig. ).

Position negative (AL) bus-bar (16) pt6a38-772001-001-0050 1 over thermocouples, and align end holes for bolt (11) pt6a38-772001-002-0035 1 at approximately 2 o'clock position and ten holes for bolts (18) with holes marked AL in thermocouples.
Secure negative (AL) bus-bar (16) to thermocouples with ten bolts (18) pt6a38-772001-001-0060 10 and washers pt6a38-772001-001-0065 10 (25, 3253). Torque bolts (REF. NO. 1084, Fits and Clearances).

Position positive (CR) bus-bar (15) pt6a38-772001-001-0070 10 over thermocouples, and align end holes for bolt (12) pt6a38-772001-002-0037 1 at approximately 8 o'clock position and ten holes for bolts (17) pt6a38-772001-001-0080 10 with holes marked CR in thermocouples.
Secure positive (CR) bus-bar (15) to thermocouples with ten bolts (17) and washers pt6a38-772001-001-0085 10 (26, 3253). Torque bolts (REF. NO. 1083, Fits and Clearances).
Do continuity and insulation resistance test of T5 system (Ref. 72-01-00, POWER SECTION - SUB-ASSEMBLY).
Measure clearance between bus-bars (15) and (16), and power turbine stator housing (1) (REF. NO. 1020, Fits and Clearances) at 40 locations.

Apply light film of jointing compound (PWC09-005) to both mating faces of gasket (7) pt6a38-772001-002-0180 1 , then install gasket on wiring harness (3) pt6a38-772001-002-0010 1 and carefully pass inner section of harness through guide tube in exhaust duct. Tube section of harness should fit centrally in guide tube when flange (5) is finally bolted to exhaust duct.
Secure flange (5) to exhaust duct with bolts (6) pt6a38-772001-002-0170 2 . Tighten bolts, torque 32 to 36 lb.in., and lockwire (PWC05-089A). Wipe off excess sealant using solvent (PWC11-032).

Install wiring harness sleeves in clips on power turbine stator housing (1) and secure with wire lacing (PWC05-089A). Lacing wire should retain harness firmly in its locating clips. The tension on the lacing wire should be such that fretting of the harness is eliminated and crushing of harness insulation is avoided. To achieve this, the lacing wire must pass with adequate tension over and under the harness, except for semi-rigid leadout where lacing must pass over the harness only

Connect negative (AL) wiring harness terminal lug (9) pt6a38-772001-002-0050 1 to negative bus-bar (16) using bolt (11) and nut (10) pt6a38-772001-002-0036 1 . Connect positive (CR) wiring harness terminal lug (14) pt6a38-772001-002-0040 1 to positive bus-bar (15) using bolt (12) and nut (13) pt6a38-772001-002-0038 1 . Torque nuts (10) and (13) 30 to 35 lb.in. Bolts (11) and (12) must be installed with heads under the bus-bars, and nuts (10) and (13) on the outside. This ensures clearance between bolts and stator housing (1).

procedure.title: T5 Function and Electrical Checks
procedure.step: Test circuit for continuity as follows: Using a test set (PWC2312G-8), connect leads to chromel and alumel terminals of lead-out harness, and measure loop resistance of the T5 system. Resistance must be between 1.4 and 1.9 ohms (3197) or 1.30 and 1.55 ohms (3197). Disconnect test set leads.

Do insulation resistance test: Using a test set (PWC2312G-8), connect one lead to chromel terminal of harness leads, and other lead to a good electrical ground such as the exhaust case. Measure insulation resistance which must not be less than 50,000 ohms Repeat steps and , preceding, with alumel terminal. Disconnect test set leads.

figure.title: Installation of T5 Thermocouples, Bus-bars and Wiring Harness (3197), and Blanking Thermocouples (3241)

procedure.step: Functional test each probe: Using a test set (PWC2312G-8), connect leads to alumel and chromel terminals of T5 leadout harness. Using a suitable heat source, such as a 100-watt soldering iron, capable of heating probe to 94°C (200°F), apply heat to one thermocouple probe. High temperatures are not required for this test. Check for positive temperature deflection on test set. Repeat test on each probe in turn. Allow heated probe to cool to room temperature before testing next probe. To reduce cooling time, a mild blast of cool air may be used.

n-para.title: General
n-para.para: Personnel overhauling the power section should acquaint themselves with general information on symbols, terms, and overhaul inspection requirement (OIR) letters (Ref. 72-00-00, FITS AND CLEARANCES) REF. numbers applicable to this section are given in Table 601 and should be read in conjunction with locations on Figure .

For applicable classes of vane ring refer to IPC.
